div.head: PROLOGUE:
div.byline: Spoken by Mr. Verbruggen, Written by Mr. Motteux.

lg.l: THIS season with what Arts both Houses strive,
By your kind presence, to be kept alive!
W' have still new things, or old ones we revive;
We plot, and strive to bring them first o'th' Stage,
Like wary Pilot for his Weather-gage.
W' have Every Act, and every week a Play;
Nay, w' have had new ones studied for one Day;
W' have double Duty, and w' have but half Pay.
W ' have scaling Monkies, and w' have dancing Swans,
To match our nimble cap'ring Chairs and Stands:
There Opera's with, and here without Machines:
Here, Scenes well wrought, and there, well painted Scenes;
Castles and Men i'th' Air, the World l'th' Moon,
Where you, like Swallows fly, but soon y'are gone.
W've something ev'ry different Taste to hit,
I gad, I think, w' have ev'ry thing but Wit;
For w' have full Scenes, and w' have an empty Pitt.
Faith, Sirs, we scarce cou'd hope, you here wou'd be
So num'rous, tho' we have a new Comedy.
For there's in Plays, you know, a Reformation
(A thing to which y' have no great inclination)
I fear you'll seek some loser Occupation.
From those Lewd Poets all these mischiefs flow;
They, like Drawcansirs, maul'd both Friend and Foe.
Wou'd they'd been serv'd like their Plays long ago!
All cautious Dons and Matrons hence they scar'd,
And all this did they do, because they dar'd.
Yet, that you're hardn'd Sinners they may boast,
The more they lash'd you, you seem'd tickled most.
But now no Luscious Scenes must lard their Plays:
No Lady now will need to hide her face;
But I'll be hang'd if one i'th' Gallery stays.
To hear ill-natur'd Truths no more you'll sit,
But mortifie an inoffensive Wit;
Lord! how still we shall have you in the Pit!
For I dare say, of what most pleas'd our Guests,
Nine parts in Ten were still sheer Bawdy Jests.
Methinks I see some here who seem to say
Gad, e're the Curtain's drawn I'll slip away;
No Bawdy, this can't be a Women's Play.
Nay, I confess there's Cause enough to doubt,
But, Faith, they say there was a deal cut out,
Then stay and use it gently, some of you,
Since to be maim'd y'are somewhat subject too.
Spare it, you who for harmless sports declare,
Show that this age a modest Play can bear.
Twice has our Poetess kind usage found;
Change not her Fortune, tho' she cang'd her Ground,

div.head: EPILOGUE:
div.byline: Spoken by Mr. Scudamore, Written by Mr. Motteux.

lg.l: SSriblers, like Bullies, sometimes huff the Pitt,
Tho their feign'd Courage has an Ague Fit;
But oftner, from a sense of their Condition,
An Epilogue resembles a Petition.
Thus they make Mr. Bays his Notion just;
If Thunder cannot save them, Halters must.
Which way to use, I swear, I do not know;
Hussing's too haughty, Cringing is too low.
I'll use the middle way; perhaps 'twill do,
At least, I fancy, 'tis most lik'd by you.
Thus then to ev'ry Judge of Wit I bow;
(I hope all the Audience think I mean them now).
If so, you'll scorn to judge of Woman's Wit;
Tho' in Wit's Court the worst of Judges sit,
Sure none dare try such puny Causes yet.
Faith, if you're strict, now there's a Reformation,
We've sworn t'invite the grave part of the Nation;
Rich Sparks with broad-brim-hats and little Bands,
Who'll clap dry Morals till they hurt their Hands;
Nice Dames? who'll have their Box as they've their Pew,
And come each Day, but not to ogle you:
No, each side Box shall shine with sweeter Faces;
None but Chains, Gowns and Coifs shall havetheir Places,
Their Chit-chat News, Stockjobbing, and Law-Causes.
The Middle-Fry shall in the Gall'ry sit,
And humh whatever against Cuckold's Writ.
And City Wives from Lectures throng the Pit:
Their Daughters Fair with Prentice trudge it hither,
And throng as they do Lambeth-Wells this weather.
Then all thus stor'd, tho' Money's scarce this Age,
We need not fear t' have a Beau-crowded Stage.
So, for new guests we'll change, just as our Beaux
Wear Doyly-Stuff, for want of better Cloths.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Sir Francis Wildlove in his Chamber Dressing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: SEarchwell!

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: — Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Get me some Small Beer, and dash a little Langoone in it; else 'twill go down my burning Stomach ten degrees colder than Ice: I should have met my old Friend and Collegian Beaumont, who came to Town last night, but Wine and Women drove it clear out of my Head.

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: Sir, he's here.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Welcome dear Friend, I prithee pardon my omission, faith 'twas business that could not be left to other hands.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Women I suppose, and that excuse I know a Man of your kidney thinks almighty.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Even so well by my Life, I am heartily glad to see you, why thou hast been an age consin'd to barren Fields and senceless Groves, or Conversation stupid and dull as they: How canst thou waste thy Youth, happy Youth, the very Quintessence of Life from London, this dear Epitome of pleasure?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Because excess of drinking cloys my Stomach, and Impudence in Women absolutely turns it; then I hate the vanity of Dress and Fluttering, where eternal Noise and Nonsence reigns; this consider'd, what should I do here?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Not much in troth.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But you, my Friend, run the Career your appetite directs, taste all those pleasures I despise, you can inform me what humour's most in fashion, what ruling whim, and how the Ladies are.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Why faith there's no great alteration, the Money is indeed very much scarcer, yet what perhaps you'l think a wonder, dressing and debauchery increases; as for the Damosels, three sorts make a Bushel, and will be uppermost: First, there's your common Jilts will oblige every body.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: These are Monsters sure.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: You may call 'em what you please, but they are very plentiful, I promise you: The next is your kept Mistress, she's a degree modester, if not kind to each, appears in her dress like Quality, whilst her ogling eyes, and too frequent Debauches discovers her the younger Sister only to the first.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This I shou'd hate for Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: The third is, not a Whore, but a brisk airy, noisy Coquette, that lives upon treating, one Spark has her to the Play, another to the Park, a third to Windsor, a fourth to some other place of Diversion; She has not the heart to grant 'em all favours, for that's their design at the bottom of the Treats, and they have not the heart to marry her, for that's her design too Poor Creature. So perhaps a year, or it may be two, the gaudy Butterfly slutters round the Kingdom, then if a foolish Citt does not take compassion, sneaks into a Corner, dies an Old Maid, despised and forgotten. The Men that sit those Ladies are your Rake, your Cully, and your Beaux.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I hope Sir Fra. Wildlove has more honour than to find a Mistress amongst such Creatures.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Gad honest honourable Ned, I must own I have a fling at all, sometimes I think it worth my while to make a Keeper Jealous, frequently treat the Coquette, 'till either she grows upon me, or I grow weary of her; then 'tis but saying a rude thing, she quarrels, I fly to the next Bottle, and there for ever drown her remembrance.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis pitty that the most noblest Seeds of Nature are most prone to Vice.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Such another grave Speech wou'd give me a sit of the Colick.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well I find 'tis in vain to tell you my Story, without I have a desire to be swingingly laught at.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Nay, Nay, why so, I'd sacrifice my life to serve my friend.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To confess the truth, I'm in Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Is that such a wonder why I have been so a thousand times? old boy.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ay, but desperately, vertuously!

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: There the Case differs, I doubt friend you have apply'd your self to a wrong Man.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Are not you acquainted with Sir Charles Beauclair?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Yes, intimately.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Then, in short, his Lady and a Booby Brother of her's have got my Mistress in their power; she was the Daughter of àn Eminent Merchant, one Sir George Venturewell, who dying left her to the care of my Lady Beauclair's Father; he prov'd like most Guardians, a great Knave, forg'd a Will, which gave my Arabella nothing, unless she married this two-leg'd thing his Son; some of her friends contested with 'em, but the Lawyers roguery, through the Guardians wealth prevail'd, and she is again in their possession; the old Fellow is dead, but the Sister and Brother pretend to manage her.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Your case is desperate, and I fear Sir Charles can do you but little service in't.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why, he lives with his Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Yes, modestly, he knows nothing of her concerns, and desires she shou'd know nothing of his: did you never hear of her Character?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: She is certainly the most disagreeable of the whole Sex, has neither Sense, Beauty or good Manners; then her humour is so implacable, the hunted her first Husband into the Indies, where he dy'd, Heaven knows when or how.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What the Devil made Sir Charles Marry her?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Even that tempting Devil Interest, she was vastly Rich, he a younger Brother, since the Estate and Title of his Family is fallen to him, and I dare swear he'd willingly give a Leg or an Arm to be freed from the intolerable Plague of a Wife, whom no Mortal can please.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Charles Beauclair is coming to wait upon your Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: I am glad on't, I fancy there's a sympathy in your humours, that will soon excite a friendship, for he notwithstanding the provocation of an ugly Scolding Wife at home, and the Temptation of a good Estate, and a handsome Fellow into the bargain, instead of making his life easie with jolly Bona-robars, dotes on a Platonick Mistress, who never allows him greater favours then to read Plays to her, kiss her hand, and fetch Heart-breaking Sighs at her Feet; with her he has oblig'd his charming Neice to be, almost always; Faith nothing but the horrible fear of Matrimony before my eyes keeps me from loving Mrs. Beauclair, she is pretty without affectation, has but just pride enough to become her, and gravity enough to secure her from Scandal: to all this add twelve thousand Pounds in ready Money.

div.stage: Enter Sir Charles Beauclair and Mr. Spendal.

sp.speaker: Sir Charl.
sp.p: And is not that last the most prevailing Argument, ha, Frank?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: No, Sir Charles, Chains of Gold wont tempt my freedom from me, but here's a Gentleman, sixt in the dull matrimonial rode, uneasie if he meets with interruption, though it throws him on the flowry fields of liberty, he's my particular friend, and labours under the pangs of disappointed Love, 'tis in your power to assist him in his delivery; I know you are compassionate in these cases.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You may promise for me to the utmost, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Fame reports you a true English Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You may Command me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Spendal aside to Sir Charles
sp.p: Dear Sir Charles, lend me one Guinea more, the Estate's Intail'd, my Father will die, and I shall get an Heiress.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Here take it, and leave lying:

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I'll be with you again at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I don't question it.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Searchwell, has there been no Letters for me, this Morning?

sp.speaker: Searchw.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Stay you at home, and if there come one, find me out with it.

sp.speaker: Searchw.
sp.p: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Come Sir Charles, shall we to the Chocolate-house, there you shall here Mr. Beaumont's Story.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: With all my heart; hark you Sir Francis, I have an Entertainment of excellent Musick promised me this afternoon, you know I cannot have it at home, so I have borrowed some Apartments of obliging Mrs. Bantum, the Indian Woman, and will try to prevail with the Ladies to come.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Dear Sir Charles Introduce me.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You'l think your hours thrown away in the Company of civil Women.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Faith I scarce dare trust your Neices eyes, they gain too much upon my heart. I am always forc'd, after I have seen her, to have recourse to the Glass, to secure my self from Romantick Constancy.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Now you talk of Romances, Introth I think I'm a perfect Knight Errant, for besides my own Lady, I'm in quest of another fair Fugitive, by the desire of her Father: Have you not heard of the Death of my Lord Belmour's Heir, and absence of his only Daughter Mariamne?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The old Lord has given me her Picture, with an earnest Petition, that I wou'd endeavour to find her; he prest me so, I cou'd not refuse it, though I have small probability of my side.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: She's now a prodigious Heiress, what cou'd be the meaning of running from all her Friends.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Too Studious for her Sex, and sell upon the Seducers of the Women, Plays, and Romances, from thence she form'd her self a Hero, a Cavilier, that could Love and talk like them; whilst her Father without consulting her, provided a Husband, Rich, but wanting all Scudries Accomplishments, this Man she call'd Monster, and finding the Marriage unavoidable, took her Jewels and what Money was in her Power, and in the Stage-Coach fled to this Populous Wilderness, if that can be proper, for here we are in Crowds conceal'd, as well as in a Desart.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: 'Twas strange.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I pity her, for I hate an Innocent inclination crost.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, your Coach is ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Allons Gentlemen.

div.stage: Scene Bellinda's Apartment, appears with a Böok.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In vain I fly to Books, the tuneful Numbers give me not a moments ease: In vain I've strove to walk in Virtues high, unerring Paths; blind, rash inconsiderate Love, has pusht me from the blissfull state, and sixt me strugling 'midst ten thousand dangers: Here sweet Bard, thou suites me well;
sp.l: My anxious hours roul heavily away;
Depriv'd of Sleep by Night or Peace by Day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Poor disconsolate Damosel, come leave this soft melancholly Poetry, it nurses your Disease.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You indeed, like a bright Ray of comfort, shoot through my endlessnight; where's my dear destruction?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Mr Spendall said he would be here at noon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He's ever here, I feel himbusie at my Heart, and when the wisht minute of his approach comes on, every Artery catches the Convulsive Joy: Dost not thou think me mad?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: A little crais'd or so, my dear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Bedlam, o're this, had been my proper mansion if your sweet Company had not composed my jarring thoughts, and given the warring Torments Intervals of rest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p:
I must confess, tho I am wild to the very verge that Innocence
allows, yet when my Uncle, that dear good man, told me, if e'er I meant to oblige him I must be a Companion, Friend, and Lover of his Mistress. The proposition startled me, but then I did not think there had been such a Mistress as my Bellinda, nor Platonick Love in real practice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: True, my dear Friend, our Love is to the Modern Age, unpractic'd and unknown; yet so strict and so severe, are rigid Honour's Laws, that tho' not grosly, yet we still offend: had not Fate fixt a bar unpassable between us, how shou'd I'have blest the accident that brought us first acquainted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: You never told me the Story.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In short, 'twas thus; coming from the Play, mask'd with a Young Lady, a fluttering Fellow seized me, and spight of my intreaties grew rudely troublesome; I was never used to such Behaviour, and it throughly frighted me; Sir Charles being near, saw my unfeigned concern, and generously made the Brute desist, then led me safely to a Coach, observing where I bid the Coachman drive, he came to wait upon me, my fair Friend agen was with me and 'twas by her perswasions that I saw him: we found his conversation nicely civil and full of Innocent delight, I blush'd, and fondly thought this man my Amorous Stars in kindness destin'd for my happiness, but oh!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: But Oh, he was married, and that spoiled all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Therein I only can accuse him of deceit: He kept his marriage a satal Secret till I had lost the power to banish him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: I prithee dear Bedinda where wer't thou bred; I'm sure this Lewd Town never gave you such nice notions of honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Friendship bars you of nothing but enquiring who I am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis true I beg your Pardon and am silent.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Only this I'll tell you, Madam, and as a warning never resolve, although you think it fully in your power, to keep your resolution. Mark it in me, I that thought to have stood the fairest pattern of my Sex; and would have blotted all the annals of guilty Love, yet now am lost fonder of my Beauclair than of Family or Fame, yet know him married, and Divine and humane Laws against me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: For Humane Laws, I know not what to say, but sure Heaven had no concern, 'twas a detested match. Ruling Friends and Curst A arice joyned this unthinking youth to the worst of Women: But no more of this how dye like your new Lodgings? The House is very large, have you no good Neighbours?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You know 'tis not my way to be acquainted; my impertinet maid sometimes teases me with a relation of a Merchant and pretty Lady; who came from the Indies and Lodge here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: What are they, Mrs. Betty?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Nay, my Lady will ne'er hear me out; but I'm sure they are worth any Bodies observation, he looks like a Surly, Old, Rich Cuff, and she like an Intriguing Beautiful Jilt, as sine as a Queen covered with Jewels.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha' done with your Description, I'm sick of 'em both.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Lord, you are so peevish, pray give me leave to ask Mrs Betty little more Questions about 'em, what's his name?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: An odd one Madam, they call him Mr. Flywife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: An odd one indeed, and contradicting his Actions when 〈◊〉 a fine Dame belongs to him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou art a little Gossip to trouble thy head with other peoples Affairs; I heard news of yoh, Madam, the other day, they say you are in Love, for all your seeming indifference.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Yes, introth I am a little that way inclined; but my Spark is indeed too far from your Cassandra rules, his Mistresses are neither Angels nor Godesses; truly Sr Francis Wildlove is too mad even for me; tho' the Devil's in't, I can't forbear thinking of the Rambler.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Vertue and Beauty may reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: It may be so; but I doubt he don't like Reforming Enter Sir so well as to try it. Ha, see who appears comely as rising day Charles. amidst ten thousand eminently known Bellinda this Heroic is designed for you, tho' somewhat barren of Invention, I was forc'd to borrow it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Chearful, and thy mind at ease, happy Girl.

sp.speaker: Sir Charles
sp.p: (taking Bell's hand) My Blessing.

sp.speaker: Beil.
sp.p: My Fate, which I shou'd, but cannot curse.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Cousin I'm glad to find you here, you shall help perswade Bellinda to go abroad; I have promised to bring you both to Mrs. Bantums, I have provided a trifle of a Dinner, and Excellent Musick for digestion; there's only a Country Gentleman and Sir Francis, I know you love Sir Francis Neice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You may be mistaken Sir; grant I did, wou'd you have me meet him? dear Uncle, don't make me so ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I thought Neice you durst have trusted me with your Conduct, my Friends are no Brainless Beaux, no Lady Libellers, that extend innocent Favours, and bespatter the Reputations they cannot ruine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Then you think your Friend Sir Francis a very modest man.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No, my Dear, but your mildest men, if they have sence, as I am sure he has, know how to treat Women of Honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Nay, I'm soon convinc'd, what say you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will go; for perhaps, Sir Charles, you think I've only invented Fears of being known, but you'll surely find, if any Accident discovers me, I shall be seen by you no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: See thee no more! yes, I would see thee, tho' barr'd by foreign or domestick Foes; set on thy side Father or Husband, on mine Wife and Children, I'd rush through all Nature's Tyes to gaze on thee, to satisfie the longings of my Soul, and please my fond desiring Eyes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Chide him Beauclair, let him not talk thus.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Before he came you were at it; what can I say to two mad Folks?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Your Servant Ladies. Sir Charles, is it not Dinner-time? I am as hungry as a—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Horse, I know the old expression; were I my Uncle, I'd as soon build an Hospital for the lazy, as undertake to satissie thy voracious Appetite.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How hast thou of late disoblig'd my Neice, that she is so severe upon thee?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Only told her Ladiship a Truth she could not bear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: A Truth from thee, I rather think I could not hear it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I said, a she Wit was as great a Wonder as a Blazing-star, and as certainly foretold the World's turning upside down; yet 'spight of that the Lady will write.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Brute! what did I ever write, unless it was thy Character, and that was so adroit, you had like to hang'd your self?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: For my sake, Cousin, for bear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Let him take pett and not come to Dinner to day, if he thinks fit, 'tis not I that care.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, I will come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: That I would have sworn.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: To give occasion, that you may draw this shining weapon Wit; it will dazzle the Assembly; if it pierces only me, no matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Stuff, pshaw, will you come, Madam, and put on your things?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Dear Spendall, I must beg of you to step to our House, I made my Wife a kind of Promise to dine with her to day.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Say I am gone to Court, she loves the Thoughts of being great, tho' most unfit for't.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: But you know you promis'd to carry her Daughter Miss Peggy with you next time you went thither.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: True; say I'm gone to the Tower: I'm call'd, say any thing the Devil puts into your Head.
Bellinda within, Are you ready?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, I shall say what the Devil puts into my Head, but not what you expect: Am I not then ungrateful? Has he not for several months fed, cloath'd and supported me? But what for, to be a meer Letter-carrier, an honourable Pimp for Platonick Love? He shall find I can employ my Parts better; he trusts me for his pleasure, and I'll betray him for mine.
Ha, Lyewell! why come you hither?

sp.speaker: Lyew.
sp.p: Phough, I saw Sir Charles and the Ladies go out: besides, I want Mony; I did not serve you so, when I was in my Lord Worthy's Family.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Prithee don't be so surly, here's a Crown for thee, but I expect some Service for't: Is there ever a Strumpet in your Catalogue so well bred as to write?

sp.speaker: Lyew.
sp.p: All the Whores in Town can scrawl if that will do.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Let one of 'em send immediately a nameless Letter to my Lady Beauclair, and inform her, That Sir Charles will be to day at Mrs. Bantums with a Whore, between three and four, by that hour, lest she come too soon and disturb our Dinner. Well, the Heiress is coming, I shall make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Lyew.
sp.p: Ay, when you marry Mrs. Beauclair.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Hang her; I hinted Love but once, and she has abus'd me ever since. I have no luck with the Wits, now I have better Chase in view, a wealthy Fool, a Fool the Perquisite of a Sharper. Come with me, and I'll instruct you further.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: O how happy am I, to breath again my native London Air! I vow the Smoak of this dear Town delights me more than all the Indian Groves: happy too in meeting with one like thee; thou understand'st Intrigues, art cunning, subtile, as all our Sex ought to be, who deal with those deluders Men.

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: Then your Ladiship lik'd not the Indies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: How was't possible I shou'd? Our Beaux was the Refuse of N●…gate, and our Merchants the Offspring of foolish plodding Cits.

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: Why went you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: So great is my Opinion of your Faith, I dare trust you with all my past life: My Friends bred me at a Boarding-school, and dy'd when I was but fourteen, leaving me nothing for my Portion but Pride and a few tawdry Clothes; I was a forward Girl, and bartering what I had not the Wit to prize, a never to be recover'd Fame was soon maintain'd in Finery, Idleness, and darling Pleasure, but the deceitful Town grew weary of me sooner than I expected, and I sick of that, seeing-other new Faces preferr'd before me; so picking up some Moneys, and a handsome Garb, I ventur'd to Jamaica.

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: Madam, I hear my Master unlock his Study.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! and this foolish Story put Sir Francis Wildlove's Letter quite out of my Mind. Have you writ as I directed?

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Give me the Letter and be gone, I would not have him think us great.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Flywife. [As Mrs. Flywife goes to put up the Letter hastily, drops it.
sp.p: Come Fubby, will you go into the Dining-room the Chocolate is ready.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: And you, methinks, are ready too, Madam; beyond Sea 'twas a courted Favour, dress'd seldom, and careless; but since arriv'd at this damn'd Town, no cost, nor pains is spar'd; Curse upon my doating Folly, that listen'd to your Prayers, and spight of my Oath and strong Aversion, brought you back to the high road of Hell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Is then my try'd Constancy suspected? Did I for this deny the richest Planters of the place, who courted me in an honest lawful way, and would have parted with their Wealth, dearer than their Souls, to have call'd me Wise, whilst I, slighting all their Offers, gave up my unsullied Bloom to you, only on your protested Love leaving Jamaica, fled with you to a remoter World, because you said your Circumstance was such, that if you liv'd with me, your English Friends must believe you dead.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Well, and what was my Return to all this boasted kindness? You may remember, Madam, your Cargo was sunk so low, 'twould scarce afford at the next Ships approach another London Topping; when I without a hated Lock for Life pour'd on ye more Riches than all your Husband-pretenders joyn'd together could aim at, gave you such a separate Fortune, that indeed I was forc'd to obey your Desires in coming into England, lest you should do't without my Leave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Well, well, thou art a good Boy, prithee no more wrangling Fubby; I vow and swear to morrow I'll be as great a Slattern as ever was, if that will please you, so I will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Ay, and want to go out to day, for all the gazing Fops to admire, tho' I have told you, I can't appear till I have enquir'd into my affairs, then to morrow, if you stay at home with me, Sackcloth will serve turn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Lord, you are so froppish, if I was your Wife, sure Fubby, you would not be so jealous.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: My Wife quotha! no, no, I was once bewitch'd, but I found such a Plague, that— No more Wives, I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Well, I'll be any thing to please Fubby; Will you go in? Our Breakfast will be cold.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: (takes up the Letter) I'll follow you.

Ha! what's here? a Sonnet, I'll warrant; her gaping abroad has brought this: A Letter of her own, only the Hand is scrawl'd to disguise it. (reads) If I were convinc'd your Passion was real, perhaps you might have no cause to complain: (fine advancing Devil) be constant and discreet, you ll find none of our Sex ungrateful. By thy burning Lust that's a damn'd Lye, for thou art thy self a most ungrateful Jilt: I'll catch her now, e're the Devil can be at her Elbow to invent a Lye, and if one wheedling Tongue does not destroy all my Senses, she shall feel my Rage.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the Captain comes to bring you News your Ship is safe in the River.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Be damn'd, there let it sink.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Shall I tell him so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Jackanapes, I'll come to him. Is it impossible in Nature to be happy with or without a Woman? If they are virtuous they are peevish, ill-natur'd, proud and coy;
sp.l: If fair and complaisant, they please as well:
For then, by Heav'n, they are as false as Hell.

div.trailer: The End of the First ACT.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: HA, ha, ha! I can't forbear laughing at your great concern. Jenn. O madam, if you did but see what a passion my master was in, you would not be so merry; he was like to beat the Sea Captain, tho' he brought him the good news of his Ships arrival.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Pho, mind what I say, and fear not; I warrant you shall have the Letter again, and liberty to find Sir Francis Wildlove with it.

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: Madam, he comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Well, well, be sure you do it handsomly.
Never, never let her be your Wife.
That was loud that he might think me merry; speak hussy.

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: (crying) Pray, madam, search again; I have been a month of writing on't, and took it out of a Book too; the man has sent me forty, before I could make shift to answer one till now: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Prithee don't tease me, I dropt it, 'tis gone, I'll write another for you, since you say the man is for a Husband, and can so well maintain you; be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: What's this? faith not improbable, 'tis not my Damosels hand, now I have consider'd on't again.

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: I had rather have lost my best Petticoat by half.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Cease your noise, or leave the Room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: What's the matter? having no occasion for a Quarrel, will be Money in my Pocket, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Why Fubby, this foolish Wench, it seems, has a Country Lover, and beg'd of me to direct a Letter to him, which in troth I have lost, so she howls, that's all, Fubby.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: And I have found it: Come Jenny, to make amends for your Sorrow, I'll write the Superscription; Whither is it to go?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: (aside to her Mistris) Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: O, I think I remember;— to Jeoffrey Scatterlove, at the Bull-Inn in Cambridge: so seal it and carry it, for these silly Girls never think it safe, unless they give it into the Post-house themselves, but make haste.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Have I got thee again, my dear sweet Letter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: A very raw foolish Girl this, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Faith Puggy, there had like to have bin a Quarrel; I was almost afraid that Letter was a piece of Gallantry of yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you are alwaies suspecting me, when Heaven knows I am such a poor constant Fool, I never so much as dream of any man but my own dear Fubby: Fubby, let I go.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: No, no, I'll run away, I won't hear you, I won't hear you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Then I ll follow, and I am sure prevail. Oh, had my Sex but half my Cunning, the deceivers would find themselves deceiv'd; from my Gallants I never found, but gave 'em killing Charms.
sp.l: Fools! when we love, our Liberties we lose;
But when belov'd, with ease we pick and chuse.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Brother, I say you're a Fool.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p:
Fool in your Face.—— I'm no more a fool than your self.— What would you have a man do?— Must I ravish her? Don't I know Accessories have bin hang'd! and here you'd have me Principal! what, I understand
Law,— I won't hang for your pleasure.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Yes, you understand Law— D'ye understand parting with a good Estate, which you must do if you han't this Arabella? Don't tell me of Ne— Ne— Necessaries, I say you shall marry her.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay, but the Craft will be in catching, as the Saying is: why, I went but e'en now to take her by the Lilly-white Hand, as the Poet has it, and she threw a whole dish of scalding-hot Tea full in my Face, Dish and all Cousin Peggy saw her; she call'd her all the names in Christendom; she'll tell ye the same.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Ah poor Peggy! ay, she don't 'ove to see you abus'd;— were that Minks like Peggy, you were but too happy. Well— when will you give Peggy that Diamond Necklace? The Sparks are almost mad for her,— she has the Lord knows how many Sweethearts; there's Squire— what d'ye call him?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: (aside) So, now she's got upon her Daughter's Sweethearts— she'll ne'er ha' done.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: There's Sir John Empty, and Mr. Flutter, and Capt. Noisy, say the finest things to her, but the Wench is so coy, and my Rogue of a Husband will let none of 'em come home to her, but calls 'em Fops, and Boars, and the Lord knows what.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: O Lord, Boars! Beaux you mean.— O Lord, Boars!

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Well, she has of all sorts,— and if there be twenty Women in company, all the rout is made about her; and the Girl doth so blush— I vow and swear it makes her look woundy handsom.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay, you call'd me fool, but I'll be hang'd if ye dan't make a fool of her, mark the end on't; marry her to some honest Tradesman, that's fittest for her.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Pray don't you trouble your musty Pate about her: No, she scorns a Citizen, she would not have my Lord Mayor's Son; she's a Girl of discretion: I was married young too, and I look'd after all my first Husband's Affairs.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: (aside) True, till he went the Lord knows whither to be quiet.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Indeed this young fellow is not worthy the Name of a Husband; I have a good mind to let the World know what a deceitful piece 'tis.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mother! mother!

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: What's the matter Child?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Here's Mrs. Arabella does nothing but jeer and abuse me; she says eating between meals will spoil my Shape, and I snatch'd a Book out of her hand, and she said a Primmer was sitter for me.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: I'll never endure this, how dare she affront my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Cheat
sp.p: So, I'm like to have a fine life, nothing but scolding and noise; for my part, I'd rather not marry at all: if she is thus randy beforehand what will she be afterwards? In a short time I shall be made Ballads on, and my Picture set before 'em just like the Summons to Horn-sair.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you shall marry her; and we'll tame her too, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Here she comes, here she comes, as mad as a Turky-cock.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Why am I us'd thus? Your Servants are forbid to call me either Coach or Chair; Are you my Jaylor? You, Oaf, I speak to.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Mistress, 'twould be better for you if you had other words in your mouth, I'll tell you that.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You shan't gallop your—

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Hold Peggy, let me speak— What's the reason, Mrs. Arabella, you take this Privilege here?— You know your Fortune is at our dispose, so shall your Person be, else you must expect nothing.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Had I but heard your Characters, I'd sooner have been expos'd a Beggar in this inhospitable World, than e'er set my Feet within your Doors.

sp.speaker: La Beauc.
sp.p: I'd have you to know our Corecters are honest Corecters; I wish yours prove so.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Don't provoke me, I say, don't.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Why? you won't beat me,— I hear there is a sensible Man amongst ye, I'll appeal to him, if you'd let me see him.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: That's my Husband you mean;— No, you shan't see him, nor such as you are, if I can help it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What I would you see my Vather-in-law, to tell Lies and Stories to him? No, no, don't mistake your self.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Away, you smell of Aqua Mirabilis.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Oh Impudence! She smell of strong Waters! She hates it.— Come hither Peggy, let me smell, thy Breath us'd to be as sweet as any Cows.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: (aside) What shall I do? I've been at my Mother's Bottle; I won't come to satisfie her nor you neither. What ails ye,— d'ye know?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No, don't, Miss.— Well, since I must have neither Attendance nor Conveniency, I'll go a-foot.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Hold ye, hold ye, you are not gone yet, as the Saying is.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Was ever Usage like this?

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Your Usage has been but too good, let me tell you that; I'll show you such Usage as you deserve. Hug— Uggun,— what a Devil is your Name? I hate a Wench with a hard Name.
Here, lock up Mrs. Flippant in the dark Room.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: (jumping about) Ay, lock her up, lock her up, I say.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: (grinning in her Face) Yet, Mrs. Bella, be rul'd by me,— give me one sweet look, and let me take a Hony Kiss, and you shan't be lock'd up;— No, you shan't be lock'd up,— but go abroad with me, and have your Bellyful of Cakes and Custards.— Shall I?— Shall I?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: There's the Kiss; and for a Look, I wish my Eyes were Basilisks.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O Lord, Mother, how she swears!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh my Chops, my Chops! lock her up; hang her, she's a Fury.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Abominable! come hither, hath she hurt ye?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Oh Eugenia! last night, when you heard my Story, you, in gentle pity, wept;— Assist me now, or I'm lost.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Have Patience, Madam, and believe me yours.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: (aside to her Brother) I say, keep the Key your self, I don't like her greatness with the Maid.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: 'Tis locking up, I fear 'tis against Law, Sister.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Pho, I fear nothing;— Are not you a Squire, and rich?— you're above the Leaw.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay; but Knights ha'been hang'd,— I dread hanging— I tremble alwaies when I think on't.

sp.speaker: La Beauc.
sp.p: Hang'd! there's no danger of being hang'd; what,— ha'ye no Courage?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Yes, I have Courage, and that she shall find; my Injuries, as I have read it, steel my Eyes. Mrs Arabella,— I could swear the Peace against you, and have you before a Justice;— but I will spare you the Shame; and punish you my self:— Come along.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Resistance is in vain,— but I will be reveng'd, or kill my self.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay, ay, kill your self, and then I shall have your Estate, without being troubl'd with your Person.— I'll humble you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And Heaven punish thee.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Don't trouble your musty Pate about Heaven, (as my Sister says) but come along.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Away with her, away with her.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I take Heaven and Earth to witness, I believe you design to murder me.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: There's no such Design; besides your Witnesses are not valid,— I never heard their Evidence go in any Tryal in all my life.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: No, it is not to murder ye, but make ye better: No more words, but let it be done.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I'm glad she's to be lock'd up,— for had any Gentlemen come to see me, she's so pert, her Tongue would ha' bin running.

div.stage: Enter Cheatall with a Key, and Gentil and Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Here I have her double lock'd, i'faith neither Window nor Mouse-hole in the Room: Gentil,— fetch my Cloak,— I'll to my Lawyer Mr. Cobblecase, for my Mind misgives me plaguily.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Shall I wait on you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: No, no, stay at home, and if any one asks for Mrs. Arabella, say, She does not lodge here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: B'w'y Sister.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Your Journey is needless, but you may go if you will; and, d'ye hear, ask Mr. Cobblecase to come and dine here, he's a Batchelor.— You should alwaies be thinking of Peggy.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O Mother, yonder's Mr. Spendall a coming,— he's grown very fine of late.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Ay, if he would leave your Vather's Company, and make out what he says about his intail'd Estate, the man is not to be despis'd.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: My Lady Beauclair, your most humble. Dear pretty Creature, yours.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Lord, Mr. Spendall, what d'ye do?— well, I wonder Peg endures it.— I'll vow and swear, Mr. Spendall, Knights presume no farther than to kiss the tip of my Daughters little Finger, and you make nothing of her Lips.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: How! make nothing of 'em! pardon me, Madam, I put 'em to the use Nature design'd:— They are as sweet as— and as soft as— Gad, I must taste 'em again to raise my Fancy.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Be quiet, let me alone, Mr. Spendall.

lg.l: Oh, give your sweet Temptations o'er,
I'll taste those dangerous Lips no more.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: You're a strange man,— but come— sing us a Song of your own— Husband says you can make Varses.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But let it be as like that as you can, for methinks that is very pretty.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: (aside) Does the Fool think I shall make it ex tempore?— however, I have one pretty near it, as it happens. I'll rather expose myself, than not endeavour to divert you, Madam.
sp.stage: [Sings, whilst the Mother and Daughter imitate his Gestures.

lg.l: AT dead of Night, when wrap'd in Sleep
The Peacefull Cottage lay,
Pastora left her folded Sheep,
Her Garland, Crook, and needless Scrip,
Love led the Nymph astray.
Loose and Undrest she takes her flight
To a near Myrtle-shade:
The conscious Moon gave splendid light,
To Bless the Ravisht Lover's sight,
And gain the Loving Maid.
His eager Arms the Nymph Embrace,
And, to asswage the Pain,
His restless Passion he obeys:
At such an hour, in such a place,
What Lover cou'd contain?
In vain she call'd the conscious Moon,
The Moon no succour gave;
The cruel Stars, unmov'd, look'd on,
And seem'd to wink at what was done,
Nor wou'd her humour save.
Vanquish'd at last by powerful Love,
The Nymph explring lay;
No more she sigh'd, no more she strove,
Since no kind Stars were found above,
She blush'd, and dy'd away.
Yet Blest the Grove, her happy Flight,
And Youth that did betray
And panting, dying with Delight,
She Blest the kind transporting Night,
And Curst approaching Day.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Thank ye, 'tis very sine, I'll vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: So 'tis indeed Mother.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Now, to leave fooling, where's my Husband?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I know not, I han't seen him these two days.— Here my Father writes to me, if I will take up, (that's the old man's Expression) and find a virtuous Woman with a Fortune, he will give me Threethousand pounds down, and settle Eight hundred a year,— and, faith, I am trying to obey ' the rich Cuff, and wean my self from my old Friends and the dear Bottle.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Ay, you do very well, Mr. Spendall; I should be overjoy'd to see you take up, and perhaps a Fortune may be found:— I'll say no more— but a thorow Reformation will produce strange matters, matters I little thought of;— but I'll say no more.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Your Ladiship must not say a word of this to Sir Charles, for then he'll forbid me the sight of this dear Creature, whose Charms alone have power to work the mention'd Reformation.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: No, no, fear not that, I han't so many Friends, to go the ready way to lose 'em.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: For my part, I don't love Vather so well, to tell him any thing of us.

div.stage: Enter a Boy with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, here's a Penny-post Letter to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: To me!

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I warrant 'tis to me, from some Spark.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p:
Stand away Hussy, 'tis durracted to my— my Lady Beauclair,— What's this [stammering at it] Mrs. Banter's the Indian House?— Read it, Mr. Spendall, some mischief, I believe. (Spend, reads) Tho' unknown, I cannot forbear, in Justice to your Ladiships Merit, informing
you, that Sir Charles, at four a clock, will be with a Mistress, at Mrs. Bantam's; use your Discretion, but assure your self it is a Truth.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: O the Villain, the Rogue! the confounded Whore! I'll tear his and her Eyes out; always at home he's sick, his Head aches, and he must lye alone: Ah, Mr. Spendall, if I should tell you the naked Truth, you'd say, he was a Viilain too; I've often told him his own with Tears, and the brazen-fac'd Villain has forswore it. My Husband with a Whore! I have no Patience; I'll go there immediately, and stay till he comes.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay, do mother, and I'll go with you, and help to pull their Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Are you both mad? Why all there love Sir Charles to that degree they'd watch and turn him back,— you'd never conceal your Passion,— your only way is to come after the hour, and then you'll certainly surprize 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: That's true; well, good Mr. Spendall stay and comfort me,— I fear I shall have my Fits, and then no two men can hold me.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I would with all my Heart, and esteem my self happy to serve you, but my Father has sent me twenty Guineas for a Token, and if I don't go this minute, the man will be gone out of Town, and carry 'em back with him.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Nay, that is not to be neglected.— Come Child, we'l go to my Cousin Prattle's, and tell her this News: my Husband with a Whore!— I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I must seize a Kiss, else I shall faint before I see you agen.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Pish, pish, I think the man's distracted.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Is this a time.— and my Husband with a Whore! I wish my Nails were twice as long for her sake.— Ah Child, thy Vather was anotherguess man than this, tho' he had Faults too. Come away: Your Servant Mr. Spendall.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: My Husband with a Whore!

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Ladies, your most obedient Slave.— Thus far Affairs go on as I could wish. Now if my Lady does but abuse Bellinda, till it come to parting between Sir Charles and she, then my Miss being out of his Tuition, I fear not her falling into mine:— She's damn'd silly, I am forc'd to let all Courtship lye in Kissing, for she understands a Complement no more than Algebra.— Well— her Wealth makes it up.— Now for Dinner.

sp.stage: Scene Changes to St. James Park.
Enter Sir Charles Beauclair, Bellinda and Mrs. Beauclair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: This Walk i'th' Park has done me good.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Twas very refreshing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Is not this better now dear Bellinda, than reading and sighing away every beauteous Morning.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Yes, if at each gazer the conscious Blushes wou'd forbear to rise, if I cou'd look upon this object of my Love and Vertue, not shrink back, it were true happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: My lovely Charmer, let me call this day mine, and oblige you to be chearful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: I warrant ye, by and by we'll be as merry as the— you know the title that sticks ahand, Uncle,— ha, yonder's Sir Francis Wildlove, for Heaven's sake step behind the Trees, whilst I clap on my Mask, and prole towards Rosamends Pond, and he, no doubt, pursues.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You will not sure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear Gravity, I will; that is, with your leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Well thou art a mad Girl, but I dare trust thee, come this way, Madam.

div.stage: Mrs. B. crosses the Stage, Sir Fran. Wildlove following at a distance.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What's there, a Woman well Shap'd, well Drest, Mask'd and alone! how many Temptations has the Devil tack'd together for a poor frail Mortal, that scarce needed half a one! the Handkercheif dropt, a fair invitation, a duce take her agility, she has been too nimble for me, however I'll venture,— Madam, by your remaining, when the whole Army of Beauties are retir'd, I should guess you Picceer for a particular prize.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Then I suppose you have vanity enough to think your well-rigg'd Pinnace worth securing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Faith, Child, I hope you wou'd not find the fraight disagrecable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Now I cou'd not have thought such a hopeful proper Gentleman, wou'd have been stragling in the Park this Hour; what, no Lady of Quality, nor Miss that appears like one to lead out to day, no Assignation? or is ' the plague upon your fine Cloths, Credit out, and Pocket empty?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Shall I tell you the truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Yes, if you can find in your heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Why then, Faith, I have an Appointment, and that with Ladys, nay, and Musick; yet if you'll be kind, my dear Chicken, they shall wait for me in vain. By Heav'n, a charming side face.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Stand off, or I vanish, but tell me what makes you so indifferent to your first engagement? the Women are Old I suppose.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Alas, very Buds, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ugly then.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Beautiful as Angels.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: What can be the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Don't you guess? why they are Vertuous. I have a Mistress there, confound me if I am not damnably in Love with her, and yet cou'd never get my self in a vein serious enough to say one dull, foolish, modest thing to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman, suppose you practis'd before you went, and fancy'd me the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: A Match.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: With Arms across.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: And the looks of an Ass, I begin, ah Madam!— how was that sigh?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Pretty well.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p:
Behold the humblest of your Slaves: see the Martyr of your
Frowns; those Arms must heal the Wounds your Eyes have made, or else I dye; they must, they must.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Hold, hold!— Sir Charles, Sir Charles, here I shall be ravish'd in the open Park.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: O Heavens! Mrs. Beauclair!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why how now Frank, in Raptures before the face of the World and the Sun!

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Pshaw, I do confess I am caught.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If you had come to any harm, Madam, you might have thank'd your self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: (aside) No great harm neither, to have a hearty Hug from the man one loves.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Madam, I humbly ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: It is easily granted, 'twas a Frolick of my own beginning.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: This Generosity wholly subdues my wandering Heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Have a care of getting into the dull, foolish, modest Road, Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: No more of that, dear madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Come, I believe Dinner stays; where's your Friend Mr. Beaumont?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: He'l be there before us.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Let's to our Chairs, I dare say the Ladies are tir'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Truly I am.

div.stage: Enter Jenny, and pulls Sir Francis by the Sleeve; he steps aside with her.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Sir, the Lady that came lately from the Indies, whom you have seen at the Play, sends you this; the odness of the Superscription she'l explain to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: O the charming Angel! dear Girl, accept my Acknowledgment, and step behind those Trees whilst I lead my Mother and my Aunt into their Chairs, I'll be with you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: O the wretched Libertine! but to take notice on't would shew too much Concern.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Sir Francis, where are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Fra.
sp.p: Here, at your Elbow, Sir Charles: Madam, may I presume to lead you to your Chair?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Yes Sir, tho' I believe, as your Affairs stand, you could 'bate the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: The greatest Affairs in Christendom should not hinder me from waiting on your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No faith, they are not of the Shape of motherly and elderly Aunts: I'll not stay here, but watch where they go, and tell my Lady what a Rambler she has chose.

div.stage: SCENE changes to a House. Enter Mrs. Flywife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p:
So with much coaksing I have got my jealous Fellow to let me go out this afternoon, on the pretence of buying things, and seeing an old Aunt,
If this Wench wou'd come and tell me where the mad Spark will be, I'll venture to give him the meeting; have you found him?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, but I perceive he's a sad wild man, he was engaged with two Masks, and wou'd fain have flamm'd me off 'twas his Mother, but I saw by their Meen and Dress they were young.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: What said he to you?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Seem'd much pleased, but shie: Bid me stay, and promis'd to return presently; I thought I should do your Ladyship more service in seeing where they went, so I dogg'd 'em to Mrs. Bantam's our Neighbour and hous'd 'em all there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Very good, and by and by, I'll to Locket's, and send for him, I fancy I know the Gentleman s humours so well, that he'll certainly forsake old acquaintance for those of a newer date, tho' he ventures changing for the worse: he seem'd eager and pleas'd, fierce and fond, and swore my Charms were unequall'd. His swearing indeed signifies but little, the Banquet o're,
sp.l: Yet sure he'll meet when Love and I invite,
For Love's his God, and leads him to delight.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: WHither so fast. Mrs. Eugenia?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Stop me not, I am upon an Act of Charity, trying to free the Immur'd Lady;—— I have been picking up all the Rusty Keys in the house, in hopes to accomplish it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Why you'll loose your place.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Hang my place,— There's not one in the Family understands a Grain of Civility, except Sir Charles; and if he speaks to me my Lady pulls my Head-cloaths off— Come I know you don't love that Lubberly. Coxcomb, your Master— E'en joyn with me, assist in Arabella's Liberty, and recover her Fortune, and I dare engage she ll make ours. Besides, to tell you the Truth, I have received ten Guineas to day, from one Mr. Beaumont, to endeavour her freedom.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: That's a most prevailing Argument, I confess. What I do is for your sake Mrs. Eugenia

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: In hopes to go snacks with the Gold. Ha, Gentil! Well, well, stay here I'll return immediately.
'Tis done, 'tis done, is this a Bird to be concealed in such a dark and Dismal Cage?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p:
Well thou art a rare Girl. O if thou cou'dst but conjure now, and
get the Writings of my Estate for me, sive hundred Pound shou'd be thy own next moment, Wench.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Say you so, Madam, Gad I'll turn Devil but it shall be done.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why what wou'd that signify to you Fool?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Well, mind the Ladies business, and let me alone to take care of yours.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: First let us take care of the 'Squire, Gad if I don't manage that Booby, I 'll give you leave to cut my Apron, and make a slobering Bibon't.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Well, what's your contrivance?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why, I'll go in again, pour down a Bottle of Red-Ink I know of, make all fast, and swear he has murdered ye. A Cross Old Woman lately, to whom he wou'd give nothing, told him, she read it in his Phys, That he wou'd come to be hang'd; which the superstitious Fool has ever since been afraid of; very indifferent Circumstances will Confirm that Fear, and bring him to a Complyance.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: My better Angel! It has a Lucky face— It looks like thee— but how must I be disposed of?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: If you please to go to Mrs. Beauclairs, Sir Charles's Neice, she's a Woman Cheerfull, Witty, and Good, and will assist you in every Thing.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I 've heard so well of her, I dare venture to be obliged to her, come let's make haste,

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Gentil, get the back door open, and let none of the Servants see us go out; I'm sure we shall be lucky, because my Termagant Lady won't be at home to day to disturb us.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Come then, I long to quit the House I have been so ill us'd in.

div.stage: Scene changes to the India House. Enter Sir Francis Wildlove.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: A Duse of all ill luck, I have lost my little Ambassadress from my dear Indian Queen, 'twas a Charmer: how can an old Curmudgeon have the Impudence to hope he shou'd keep such a lovely Creature to himself? For a Husband or Cully, I find by her discourse, she has, and by the Description, she hates him, which is a good step for me.

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: Sir, all the Company is coming into this Room, to hear the Musick.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Gad so, are they? then I must wait upon Mrs. Beauclair down. Sirrah, you are a purblind Dog, not to find the pretty Letter-Carrier.

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: I think I see a Woman as soon as another, else I'm sure I were not fit for your Honour's Service. I'll swear she was not in the Park: I searcht it three times over as carefully as I had been to look a Needle in a Bottle of Hay, and hang'd if I did not find it.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What a Comparison the Puppy has! D'ye hear, if you do not find her out, I shall Discard you for an Insignificant Blockhead, for I am Damnably and Desperately in Love with her Mistress.

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p:
Ah Lard, Ah Lard, Desperately and Damnably in Love with her, and never saw her but twice at a Play, and then she was in a Mask. Well my Master wou'd be the best of men if 'twere not for these Whores I am
harassed off my Legs after 'em; the Pox, the Plague, that belongs to 'em, consume 'em all I say.

div.stage: Enter Sir Charles, Beauclair, Sir Francis Wildlove, Beaumont, Spendall, Bellinda and Mrs. Beaumont.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ladies, how d'ye like your small Regalio?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Extreamly; for ought I know, Sir Charles, you may report shewing me the way to gad abroad.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What Opinion, Madam, do you think this Gentleman will have of us, for I presume the young Ladies in the Country are not so free of their Company?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: No, poor Gentlewomen— They are Condemned to the Government of some Toothless Aunt or Grannum, visit but once a year, and that in the Summer season, when the heat covers the Ruddy Lasses with sweat and dust. The Winter they divert themselves with Blindman's Buff among the serving men; where, too often, one sprucer than the rest, whispers Love to Miss Jenny, and seduces even the Eldest Daughter.

sp.speaker: Beaumont.
sp.p: Tho' some have been guilty of those weaknesses, you must not accuse all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: All who are confin'd there, never suffer'd to see the World— for granting one more thinking than the rest, who has power and obeys her Father, in suffering the Addresses of the next adjacent 'Squire, she either dies of a Consumption (Pining after pleasures more refin'd) or else o'recome with Vapors, runs melancholly mad.

sp.speaker: Beaumont.
sp.p: (to Bell.) Madam you sigh'd at this pretty Description.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did I?

sp.speaker: Beaumont.
sp.p: Both her deportment and face confirm my suspitions.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You are thoughtfull, Frank.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Wou'd you have him brisker, Uncle? 'tis but my clapping on a Mask, and 'tis done. Sir Francis, do I wrong you, have I not seen you at a Play slighting all the bare-fac'd Peauties, hunting a Trollop in a Mask with pains and pleasure; Nay, more for her gaping Nonsensical Banters, neglecting immortal Dryden's Eloquence, or Congreve's unequall'd Wit..

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: I own sometimes I divert myself with the little Gypsies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Ay, and disturb the Audience.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I must speak freely, tho' you are a Woman of Quality, and my Friend's Neice, you talk so prettily, 'tis pity you shou'd not do it often in a Mask: But then agen, you are so pretty, 'tis pity you shou'd ever wear one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: I did not design by railing to beg a Compliment; Sir Charles, where's the Musick?

lg.head: A Song by Mrs. P—, Sung by Mr. Hodgson.
lg.l: WHen I languish'd, and wish'd you wou'd something bestow,
You bad me to give it a Name;
But, by Heaven, I know it as little as you,
Tho' my Ignorance passes for Shame:
You take for Devotion each passionate Glance,
And think the dull Fool is sincere,
But never believe that I speak in Romance
On purpose to tickle your Ear.
To please me then more, think still I am true,
And hug each Apocryphal Text:
Tho' I practice a thousand false Doctrines on you,
I shall still have enough for the next. [A Dance.

div.stage: A Dialogue, between two Platonic Lovers: The Words by Mr. Motteux, and set by Mr. Eccles.

lg.l: HOw long must I the hours employ
To see, be lov'd, yet ne'er enjoy?
Tho' to curb loose desires I try,
Sure I may wish at least to die?
Dye then, Poor Strephon, wretched Swain;
Nor only live to love in vain,
Live, hopeless Lover, while Igrieve
Much for thy Fate, but more for mine;
For mine, my Dear, Condemn'd to live,
To Love, be Lov'd, yet ne're be thine.
Oh, See me, Love me, Grieve me still,
Till Love's excess, or Sorrow's kill,
'Tis not my self I Love, but thee,
Then I must dye to set thee free.
No, Live and Love, tho' hope is dead;
For 'tis a Virtue so to Love:
The Gold's refin'd, the Dross is fled,
The Martyrs thus in Flames improve.
Then let us Love on, and never Complain,
But Fan the kind Fire, and Bless the dear Pain.
For why to Despair shou'd true Lovers be driven?
Since Love has his Martyrs, he must have his Heaven.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: My Lady Beauclair will be here strait, I'll e'en march off.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: What, desert us, Jack! tho' the Ladies won't drink, you may.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, Sir Charles,— I have made an Assignation with some Women of Quality of my Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Women of Quality! what, your Landresses Daughter, or some pert, fleering, tawdry Thing of a Shop, vain, and proud to lose what she understands not, her Reputation; she also brags, she's coming to Quality when she meets you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I shall not expose their Names, to convince your Ladiship of their Rank.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O, by no means debar the Gentleman of his Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: You see the Ladies are willing to dismiss you, Jack.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I'm their very humble servant.

div.stage: Immediately after Enter Lady Beauclair, (pushing away a Servant Maid) and Mrs. Peggy.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Ye lye, ye damn'd Quean, he is here,— ha!— and his Minion with him!— let me come at her—

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Hell and Furies! my Wife!— Madam, why all this Rage? Don't you see my Neice? the other is a Friend of hers, a Woman of Honour.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Your Neice is a Pimp, and she's a Whore! I'll mark her— Sirrah— Villain! Oh, oh my Fits! my Fits!

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Fly, my Bellinda, from her brutal Rage, whilst I Wedlocks slave stay and appease this hateful storm.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis but what I ought to have expected; 'tis just I should be punish'd, to prevent my being guilty.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Dear Beaumont, carry this injur'd Lady off, whilst we bear the brunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Go to my Lodgings, Child.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Any where, to Death or Hell, if there can be a greater Hell than what this Bosom feels.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O Lo. O Lo. I believe my Mother's dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: You know the contrary; these Fits are a new Trick Nature has furnish'd the Sex with.— Heretofore Tears and Smiles were the highest part their Dissimulation could attain.
sp.stage: All this while Lady Beauclair has been saintly striving, as in a Fit, and now shrieks out— Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Give her some Water.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Give her some Wine, else you'l disoblige her more, to my Knowledge, than the Fits.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: (aside) And well thought on,— I'll steal behind and drink a Glass of Wine,— my stomach's a cold.
sp.stage: Goes to the Side-table, whilst they are about the Chair and drinks two or three Glasses of Wine.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: (starting up) No, Villain, Devil! I'll drink none of your Wine,— it may be poison'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Oh, you had not lost all your Senses, you could hear, I find.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Rogue, and I'll make thee seel, I'll tear thy Linnen, Hair, thy cursed Eyes.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Hold, Madam, as I'm a Gentleman, use me like one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Sir Francis, here's an excellent Argument on your side, here's Matrimony in its true colours.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra.
sp.p: No, Madam, her Carriage is not a Satyr on the whole Sex,— it but sets off better Wives.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Yes, you were a Gentleman, and that was all, when I married ye, the poor third Brother of a Knight, 'twas I brought your Estate; if since by your Friends death one has fell, must I be abus'd, sit rah?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Madam, you have not been abus'd; you know that I was in my Nonage married, saw not with my own Eyes, nor chose for my unhappy self; e're I liv'd with ye, I possess'd an Estate nobler, a larger far than yours, which you have still commanded; nay, I have often ●…g'd ye to Diversions, in hopes it would have alter'd that unquiet mind, but all in vain.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Divartions! what Divartions? Yes, you had me to the Play-house, and the first thing I saw was an ugly black Devil kill his Wife, for nothing; then your M●…idate King o' the Potecaries, your Timon the Atheist, the Man in the Moon, and all the rest— Nonsence, Stuff, I hate 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I need say no more,— Now, Madam, you have shown your self.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Shown, what have I shown? send for your Gilflurt to show: I have shown nothing but a vartuous Face.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: All Virtue does not lie in Chastity, tho' that's a great one.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Well Cousin, I'm sorry to see you take such Courses, I would not have my Peg like you for the Varsal World. Peg, what a Colour this Child has got! fretting for me, I'm afraid, has put her into a Fever.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let's compose these Differences; your Anger is groundless— upon my Word. Not well, pretty miss! will you drink a Glass of Wine?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, I thank you,— I cannot abide it.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Poor Girl, she never drinks any thing strong, except she's very sick indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: And she's very often sick, poor Creature!— about some five or six times a day.— Madam, shall I wait on you home? I think we may quit this place with Shame enough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Peg.
sp.p: (to her Mother, aside) Don't be Friends, for Mr. Spendall sent me word, he'd meet us in the Park, and if Vather goes with us, how shall that be?

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: I dan't intend it;— No, Hypocrite, you shan't stir a step with me, if thou dost, I 'll make a bigger noise below, and raise the House about thy Ears. Come Peg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: My Aunt's Noise is her Guard, none dare approach her.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Her going out can't be more ridiculous than her coming in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Sir Charles, Let not your noble Courage be cast down.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Outragious Clamours are no News to me; but I dread how my Bellinda may resent it.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: I wonder, Sir Charles, you have Patience to live with this violent Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: 'Tis for my Fair one's sake, who, nicely jealous the World would say she had occasion'd our parting, has sworn never to see me more, if I attempt it.

sp.speaker: Searchw.
sp.p: (aside to Sir Fran.) Sir, Sir, the Lady you are so damnably in love with sends word, if you disengage your self from your Company, she'l be at Locket's in half an hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Is it so, i faith?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: (to him) Coxcomb, what need you ha' spoke so loud? Tell him I'll not fail to wait on him. Well, Sir Charles, you'l to Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: No, I'll first go home, and try to stop the farther Fury of my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Madam, I had Hopes you would have done me the Honour to let me wait on you this Afternoon, but it has happen'd so unluckily, that an old Uncle of mine, to whom I am much oblig'd,—

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: (aside to him) Oh, I'm your Uncle's Servant. Sir, there needs no Excuse, your Company being at this time a Favour I neither expect nor desire.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha
sp.p: Will you go in a Chair, Neice, or in my Coach?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: A Chair if you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: To that give us both leave to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to speak a word to my Boy first.. Will.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Run to my Woman, and bid her come to her Aunts immediately, and bring me the Suit Sir Charles made for the last Ball, and left at my Lodgings: make haste, fly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Hang it, 'tis but one ridiculous thing, I'm resolv'd to do it, I'll find these Pleasures out, that charm this Reprobate; Mony will make all the Drawers mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I'm ready to go.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Madam, be pleas'd to accept my Hand.

div.stage: SCENE changes, Beauclair's Lodgings, Enter Beaumont leading Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: Now, Madam, you're safe in the Lodgings of your Friend, forget the Rudeness past.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Forget it! impossible; her Words, like Poisonous Shafts, have pierc'd my Soul, and will for ever dwell upon my Memory with endless painful Wracks; yet look not on me as that vise Creature she has represented, but believe me, Sir, I engag'd my Heart too far, before I knew Sir Charles was married. When I found my Love unjust, how exquisite the Torment prov'd,
chill'd, with Watchings, Sighs, and Tears, yet 'spight of my Distractions, spight of the rising Damps and falling Dews, 'twas grown too great to be extinguish'd, 'till this last storm has torn it by the Roots to spring no more.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: Her every word and looks confirms my Thoughts. Madam, this I dare presume to say, both from his Character and my small Acquaintance, Sir Charles Beauclair has moral Virtues, to our late English Hero's unpractis'd and unknown; yet if I might advise, you should never see him more, or only to take an everlasting Leave.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Freedom, I confess, is strange, and your Advice is what I had resolv'd on before.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: None but the lovely Mariamne could with such becoming Majesty have check'd a Stranger's boldness. View well these Lines, and then confess if they do not the resemblance bear of a soft charming Face you have often by reflexion seen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha! my own Picture, one of the effects of my dear Mothers fondness, which she, dying, left in my Father's Hands; he nam'd me too; then let everlasting darkness shrond me; let me no more behold the Sun or human kind, forget the World, as I would be of that forgotten.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: Turn, Madam, and look upon me as your Friend; if you would still remain unknown, my Breast shall keep this Discovery silent and safe as Secrets buried with the dead: Your Father gave me that Picture, with Desires so tender for your return, that, I confess, they mov'd me: I undertook the enquiry, tho'scarce could hope to have succeeded. Since your absence your Brother's dead; so that your Father, hopeless and childless, mourns, and says your sight would revive him more than when he first bless'd Heaven for your happy birth and Mothers safety.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Brother dead!— lov'd Youth! I grieve thy untimely Fate, but thou art gone to rest ' and Peace, whilst I am left upon the wrack: Sir, I read in all your words a piercing Truth and an unbyass'd Honour, they have set my Errors full before me, my fled Duty returns as swift as I will do to this wrong'd Parent, hang on his aged Knees, nor rise till I have found Forgiveness and my Blessing there.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: Tho' much I wish your Honour and your Fame secure, yet to part such Lovers, whom this lewd Age will scarce believe there ever were, grates my very Nature.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! let me not look back that way, but generously assist me on, till that dear man, who, witness my Disgraces, I value more than all Earth's richest Treasures. Tell him, lest he should take it ill of you, that I have confess'd my Birth, and have resolv'd to fly from him and all the World, and in my Father's House remain as in a Cloister.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: How will he brook the Message?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! tell him, Sir, that the pangs of parting will scarce excel those my strugling Virtue gave at every guilty meeting, for there was Guilt: tell him I have sworn to die if he pursues. I blush to impose all this on you; but if a Lover, sure you'll forgive my Follies.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: I'll tell him all, but I must send him too, a parting Kiss, at least, which must be allow'd to such unequal'd Love.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Not till all is fix'd for my remove, then I once more will see him, tho my Heart-strings crack, I'll conquer all these criminal Fires; I have the Goal in view, bright Honour leads me on, the part is glorious, but, oh! 'tis painful too: Let me retire, and tear him from my doating Thoughts, or in the bitter Conflict lose the use of Thought.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: How strong are the Efforts of Honour where a good Education grounds the Mind in Virtue! this unexpected hurry has for some moments banish'd my dear Arabella from my Thoughts. O, here comes my Implyment! well, how goes Affairs?

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: Rarely, Sir; the Chambermaid swallow'd the Guineas as glibly as a Lawyer a double Fee from his Client's Antagonist; she's bringing the young Lady hither. Eugenia talks of a Contrivance, that you should instantly appear like a Tarpaulin, pretend to be related to the Lady, and fright the 'Squire into a complyance.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: Any thing to serve my Arabella, we'l meet 'em, and receive their Instructions.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: SCENE a Room in Locket's, a Table with a Flask upon it.
Enter Sir Francis Wildlove and Mrs. Flywife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: WEll, this is a strange mad thing, but my old cross Fellow will never let me take a mouthful of Air; I am sure you will have an ill Opinion of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: A kind one you mean, Madam; I think you generous, lovely, and all my Heart desires.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: My Maid is gone the Lord knows where for Fruit; I swear I tremble, coming into a Tavern alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: A Glass of Wine will recall the fled Roses, but here's the Nectar thirsty Love requires.
sp.stage: (Kisses her. (Mrs. Beauclair bounces in, in Mens Clothes.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beauc.
sp.p: O pardon and protect me; I'm pursued by Hell-hounds, Bailiffs, and if taken, inevitably ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: The Devil take thee and the Bailiffs together, for an interrupting young Dog.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beauc.
sp.p: You look with a Face cruel as they, but sure in those fair Eyes I read some Pity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: [aside] A very handsom Fellow, how came you in Trouble, Sir? (to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beauc.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, I was put to an Attorney, but longing to turn Beau, have half-ruin'd my Master, wholly lost my Friends, and now am follow'd by the several Actions of my Taylor, Sempstress, Perruke-maker, Hosier, and a long Et cetera; besides, the swingingst Debt my Perfumer; Essence and sweet Pouder has compleated my Ruin.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra.
sp.p: 'Tis monstrous to cheat honest Tradesmen in dressing up a Fop; therefore, unwelcoming Intruder, I desire you would seek your Protection elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Nay, now you are too severe; the young Gentleman in Liberty may mend his Fortunes, and live to pay his Debts; he has a promising Face.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Your Pity, Madam; but hastens absence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: (aside) Will this Fellow, I thought I had so well instructed, never come?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir Francis, a man out of breath says he must speak with you, on what concerns your Friend's Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: The Devil's in the Dice to day; where is he? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: (aside) Now Impudence and Eloquence assist me, what have I done? in seeking to preserve my Liberty, I have for ever lost it; my unexperienc'd Youth ne'r view'd such Charms before, and, without Compassion, this Bondage may be worse than what I avoided.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
