sp.p: (laughing) Meaning me, sir?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Nay, I m a Fool, for Bankrupt in Wealth how can I hope to thrive in Love, since scarce any of your fair sex, tho' merit was thrown into the scales, value a man on whom Fortune frowns.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: (aside) I think it is the prettiest Youth I ever saw, I have Wealth enough to supply his wants, what should then debar me?

sp.speaker: Mrs Beau.
sp.p: So; she eyes me kindly I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Your Looks, sweet Youth, plead powerful as your Language; and to let you see I value not Riches, the want of which makes you miserable, accept this Ring, 'twill stop a Creditor's mouth, and pay two or three Ordinaries at the blue Posts:

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Oh wondrous Bounty! thus encourag'd, shall I beg another Favour, that you would fly from hence before that angry man returns, lest I fall a sacrifice to his Jealousie, and see those charming Eyes no more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: If my maid would come,— ha! here she is; sure you have flown.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, Madam, I ne'er went, Sir Francis's Gentleman and I were solacing our selves below, and sent a Porter for the Fruit till hearing. Sir Francis was gone in a great hurry, he ran after his Master, and I came up to see what was the matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: A hopeful Mistress and Maid! deliver me from these Town-Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Ungrateful man, on any Pretence to leave me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Ungrateful! monstrous; had a thousand Friends been dying, they ought all to have expir'd e're you have suffer'd a moments neglect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: This Flattery's too gross, young Courtier, you must treat me with Truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: All is Truth, my Heart, my Life is yours.

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: (aside) Another Spark! sure the Devil's in my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Well Sir, I'll consent to your Desires, and we'l go from hence at the Door towards the Park, there's no danger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: If you are kind, I fear none, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Let me find you what you seem, and you shall brave the World, and scorn your Debts: Jenny, get me a Chair, and show this Gentleman the House where we lodge, then come in, let him ask for you, if you can prevent your Master's seeing him do, if not, say it is one you waited upon in his Infancy, the disparity of Years between you consider'd, that may pass.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: (aside) Humph, I shall never like him for this Affront. Yes, Madam, it shall be done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Your Hand, dear obliging Creature, I hear a noise.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Quick, this way: run you before, and pay one of the Drawers for this Flask of Champaign.

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis, Searchwel, and a Drawer.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Ha! gone! so I thought; eternal Dog, you have been helping in this Contrivance; Did you take me for a Cully, Spawn of Hell? Have I known this damn'd Town so long, at last to be catch'd with such a gross Banter? speak Sirrah; who was that Impostor that told me my Friend Mr. Beaumont was taken up for a Jacobite, and the Mobb was pulling him to pieces?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: As I ever hope to outlive your Anger, and taste agen your noble Bounty, I knew nothing of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra.
sp.p: Shut the Door, you careless Blockhead, whom I charged to watch and let no body come up to me: Now sirrah confess, or I'll make that Rogue help me kick thee into Mummy, for tho' my Sword's drawn, I scorn to hurt thee that way.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: If I should confess you'l kill me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Truly then, Sir, the young Spark gave me a Guinea to show him the Room where your Honour was; but for the Fellow that seem'd so much concern'd, I wish I may be hang'd if I knew of him any thing at all Sir, any thing at all Sir. Good your Honour break my Head, and forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: I will not touch thee; Could I expect more from thy sordid Soul? Gold corrupts Mankind; be gone.
This unaccountable Jilt has so abus'd me, I could find in my Heart to forsake the Gang, and lay a penitential Dunce at the feet of Virtue, fair Mrs. Beauclair.

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: I pray Heaven keep you in that good mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Good lack, canting sot, I suppose you was shut up with a Whore, Rascal, whilst you ought to have been Pimping for me.

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: Trim Tram, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran
sp.p: How, Impudence!

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: I meant the Rhime should be, Like Mistress like Maid; for indeed I was employ'd with my Ladies waiting Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Was ye so, Rascal? could I but find the young stripling, 'twould be some satisfaction: Hang't, if I am baulk'd both in Love and Revenge, the cross Adventures shall be drown'd in brisk Champaign:
sp.l: 'Tis the dear Glass which cases every smart,
And presently does cure the taking Heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Oh Dresswell! I'm glad I've met with thee.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, I have been in a sad fright for ye; and hunted up and down this hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: All's well, let's in there, I'll tell you my adventures.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Then I hope your Frolick has been to your Ladiships satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I got Sir Francis's Mistress from him, and faith I was pursuing my Conquest, and venturing to her Lodging, when coming to the House, it proved that where Bellinda Lodg'd and the Lady, I suppose, the Merchant's Wife. I feared I shou'd meet with my Uncle there, and fairly gave the Maid the drop. Come, I long to change my Cloaths, I'm quite tir'd with wearing the Breeches; this way.

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Wildlove and Searchwell.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Ha! is not that the young Devil that abus'd me? he has entred the House, and I'll be with him presently, walk hereabouts till I come out.

sp.speaker: Search.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

div.stage: Scene changes to the inside of the House. Re-enter Mrs. Beaumont and Dresswell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Are my things ready and a good fire in the Room.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Madam, they are?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Peep out and see who knocks;

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis Sir Francis Wildlove, and he seems in a fury.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Let him in, I'll do well enough with him; now get you gone and fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: So, Sir, I suppose you think matters have gone swingingly on your side, and have laught immoderately at the reflection how those green years have made a Fool of me; but Chance has thrown me on thee once agen, and now for those Feasts of Joy an after reckoning (Draws) must be paid young Gentleman, you understand my meaning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p:
Yes, and will answer it, but hear me first, 'tis to provoke you I speak: know then, your Mistress was my easy Conquest, I scarce had time
to say one soft thing before she cry'd, Let's fly, sweet youth, e'er that rough man returns, and in thy arms forget him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: She's a Jilt and for a well-drest Fop wou'd quit a man that saved her life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Then this Ring was presented, I suppose you may ha' seen it; adorn thy fair hand, and with ten thousand kisses 'twas whisper'd, you shall not want for Gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Tho' I value her no more than I do thee, yet I will have thy life for harbouring so damn'd a thought, that I was fitter for your sport. Come on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir Francis I'll not pretend to take your Sword, tho' I cou'd your Mistress from ye, see my Credentials for my Cowardice.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Mrs. Beauclair— What a blind Puppey am I, twice in one day, that's hard I faith?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Pray return your Lady back her favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Nay, look not concerned, upon my word I'll never interrupt you more: Hug in your Bosom the plaister'd mischiefs, their blotted Souls and spotted Reputations, no Varnish can cover o'er, pursue, o'ertake, possess, the unenvied 'mongst the Painted Tribe most worthily bestow your heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Think ye so meanly of me, my heart bestow'd amongst your Sexes shame! No, Madam, Glorious Virtue alone can reach at that, my loving is a diversion I can soon take off.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: That's hard to believe, but I must beg your pardon, I'm in haste to unrig.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Hear me a moment, you have seen my frailties, if like Heaven you can forgive, a truer penitent or a more constant votary no cruel Virgin ever found.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Have a care of the dull road: Sir Francis, Farewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Go thy ways for a pretty witty agreeable Creature, but if I shou'd seduce her into Matrimony, I fear the common fate will attend her Beauty, quickly tarnish and good humour vanish.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Ha, Lywell! I am the happiest man alive, almost out of Fortune's Power.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: What is't transports you so? some whim, some Chymical delusion, that will fail in the projection, and vanish into Air.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Hear me and then with admiration, be dumb; nor dare to contradict my wit, or Plots agen: In short, my Lady Beauclair and Miss, are in open Rebellion by my perswasion, and to Compleat my good Fortune, I have borrow'd ten Guineas of Sir Charles, with the help of which, I'll be married to his Daughter in-Law, within these two hours.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: Ha! I begin to think the Devil has left playing at Leger de main with thee: and having secur'd thee, resolves to bestow some of this World's wealth upon thee.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Canst not thou procure a Templer's Chamber for an hour or two; and appear with the Gravity of a long Robe?

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: With ease, I know a young Spark that has sine Lodgings there; but by his old Father is kept at short allowance; a Treat or a very small sum will engage that, and all his habiliments.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Canst thou not put on the grave look of a starcht Councellor.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: Hum! hum!— I'll speak with you immediately— you see, Friend, I'm busy— How was that—

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Pretty well. Come; about it presently, and I'll bring the Ladies to you, as my Father's chief Lawyer. Be sure you tell 'em, you have the settlement of his Estate upon me in your hands, and seem very desirous I shou'd do well.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: I warrant ye, and shan't we have lusty treats, old Boy?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I thought your Conscience had scrupled the proceedings.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: O'Pox, my Conscience never tsoubles me, but when Affairs go ill.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Well, make haste, and doubt not feasting: I must to my Charge, lest they cool 〈◊〉 Fools are seldom long resolv'd, and I know a finer Fellow wou'd get both Mother and Daughters heart; They're now in a kindly growing warmth, and the old one's Imagination tickled as much with thoughts of darling Peggy's Marriage, as ever 'twas with her own, Farewell! be sine you observe your directions.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: It shall be done, dear lucky Devil (Coughs) Hum, hum, I shall be perfect in a Grave Cough; and a hum, of business, by that time you come to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Hold! for I had forgot— Whereabouts is this Chamber? for I guess your Worship's Name is not so famous to direct.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: Come, as we go along I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: So my dear deliverer, how have you succeeded?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, the poor 'Squire's frighted out of the little wit he had, one Scene more, and the Day's our own.

sp.speaker: Arab
sp.p: What 's become of Mr. Beaumont?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: He's about some earnest business of Sir Charles Beauclair's, I know not what 'tis, but there's a heavy Clutter amongst 'em

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well, you brought me to the Ladies Lodging, but I believe that's the only place she is not to be found at, for I have waited in vain with much impatience to see her.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Her Footman's below, and says she'll be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Prithee let's into the Chamber first, and you shall give an Account of the 'Squire's fright?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I follow you, Madam.

div.stage: SCENE, Sir Charles Beauclair's House. Enter Sir Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p:
Sure the World's all running mad; or else resolved to make me so; at home I cannot meet with a sensible Answer; but— Oh, what touches nearest, the Dear, the cruel, the charming Maid; Bellinda will not see me
how shall I appease the offended fair, my Wife too not returned; where will this end?— Gentil! Eugenia! James.
Within. Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Sir;— Where, ye everlasting Dormice? will none come near me?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Gadzooks! This Councellor Cobblecase has talkt Law, and drank Claret with me, till my brains are turn'd topsy-turvy. Gad, I wou'd not have my Lady-Sister see me now for a King's Ransome, Tho'— udsbores! I know not why she shou'd, because she's a little older, set her eternal Clack a running upon all my Actions.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady and Miss are both abroad.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: That's well!— Why, Gentil! here Cobblecase advises me not to look up the young woman, but to use her kindly, and, Gadzooks! I'm in a plaguy loving humour— I'll try her good nature once again— Hold— yonder comes Sir Charles— My Sister will never forgive me, if I let him see her; He's a well spoken man, if I durst trust him, he shou'd sollicite for me, but then he's so woundy handsome, and so amorous, I doubt he'd speak one word for me, and two for himself; as the saying is.

div.stage: Enter Sir Charles Beauclair, talking to Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You say— you will not injure the 'Squire.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No, not in the least-she hath sworn never to marry him, and the Law will in time recover her right: Only this way is sooner and cheaper.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: The Lady's free, and I'll neither oppose or assist it further— Ha●… there he stands, how is't Brother?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Very well, I thank you, Sir Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Brother, you never care for my Company! you take me for a Nump-Scull; a half-witted Fellow, and, udsbores, wou'd you but ha' me to the Tavern, you shou'd find, I cou'd Drink my G'ass, Break my Jest, Kiss my Mistress with the best of ye— Flesh! Try old Barnaby Cheatall, at your next Jovial meeting.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You're merry, Sir— But I'm in haste.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Udsbores! Women and Wine (both Unwholsom) Punish ye— There's a Taste of my Wit in my Cursing, as the whole Cargo o' the Bullies lies in swearing— There 'tis agen, I faith! Am not I damnable Ingenions, Gentil? Live and Learn, Sirrah, and be Hang'd, and forget all, as the saying is— what a Dickins ails me! Hanging never comes in my Mouth, but a Qualm comes o're my Stomach— That curs'd old Woman! Didst observe how she look'd like the Witch, before the last new Ballad?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: She had indeed, a very Prophetick Face.

div.stage: One knocks, Gentil opens the Door— Beaumont Enters, Drest like a Seaman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Who wou'd you speak with, Sir?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: With Mrs. Arabella Venturewell.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: She's not here.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Now, by the Cannon's Fire, 'tis false— I have come ten Thousand Leagues to see her— and will not be so answered.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: A terrible Fellow! Gadzooks,— Pray, Sir, what's your business with her?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: She's my Sister; that's sufficient for your Impertinence.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You, the Lawfull Begotten Son of Sir George Venturewell, begging your Pardon, I believe you are mistaken, Friend, in your Father, as many a man may be; for Sir George had never any but this Daughter.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No, I 'm not his Lawfull begotten Son, not the weak off-spring of—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: O Lard! what pains he takes to tell me he's the Son of a Whore?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Born in India; Bred a Bucanier: Sword and Fire have been my play-Fellows, and Ravishing my Pleasure— In far distant Worlds I have scattered my rough Image, and as my Sword has cut off their dull Breed, so my vigorous youth has left a Race of future Hero's.

sp.speaker: Cheat
sp.p: A very terrible Fellow, as I hope for mercy?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Rich with the spoils of long successfull War, I have visited this Climate in search of Arabella, whom I have often heard my Father mention with much tenderness, I am directed hither— Therefore do not raise my Fury with delays For Cause, or not Cause, if I am Angry, Blood must appease it.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: O Lard! O Lard! what shall I do? He'll fright me into a Kentish Ague: I must speak him fair— Good Sir, all your desires shall be fulfilled, have but a minute's patience. Come along, Gentil, come along, and help me, intreat her to speak him fair, or I'm a lost man!
— I'll wait upon ye in a Twinkling, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: It works as I cou'd wish, it goes against me to terrify this Fool so much, but he deserves it.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh! Gentil! what shall I say.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: The Lord knows, I don't.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well, Sir, where's my Sister?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Alas! I think she's vanish'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How! d'ye trifle with my Anger, bring me stories sit for a Baby! Blood and Thunder! if I Unsheath my Sword, it finds a Scabbard in your Guts! Confess— or by the Cannons fire.—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I do confess, that thinking of your coming, and knowing her to be a little wild, lest she shou'd have been out of the way, I lockt her up— But what is now become of her, by the Cannons fire, the dreadfullest Oath I ever heard! I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: (aside) I shall never hold laughing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Oh! my Conscience!— My tortur'd Conscience!— I cannot keep it!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Oh! I went into the Room, where the Lady was lockt up: And there's at least a Pail full of blood— all the Water in the Sea will never wash the stains out— I believe 'Squire Barnaby and Gentil have killed her, cut her to pieces, and carried her away under their Cloaks.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p:
Oh! Impudence! O Lard! O Lard! Sir, I han't the heart to kill a Chicken! I always swoon at the sight of my own Blood: speak Gentil, why
thou hast never a Cloak— That's a strong proof, Sir— Gentil has ne'er a Cloak.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why then it went all under yours— Besides, Gentil has a large pair of Trowsers; that I'll swear— For you made him bring my Lady home half a Venison Pasty in 'em, (Shrieks out.) Ah! look o' their Shoes, they have Padled in it.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis so, and so I'll be Reveng'd— Cut thee small as the first Atoms that huddled up thy senseless Carkass— nor will I be troubled to bear thee hence, but stamp thy vile Clay to it's kindred Dust, and leave thee here for Rubbish?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, upon my knees I beg you'd hear me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: (interposing) Hold, Sir, don't kill the Miscreant, that will bring your self into trouble; Our Law will hang him, I warrant ye. What made him order her (being here) to be denied.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay, Good Sir, let me be hang'd! That's my Destiny! I see there's no avoiding it— Gentil— Beg I may be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let my Master be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well, I'll try your Law— if that fails, this, I'm sure never will. How must we proceed, Madam?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I'll go with ye for a Man, with the Staff of Authority, he shall order him— The very Stones in the Street wou'd turn Constables, to seize such a Monster— Kill a pretty Lady— and cut her to pieces— oh horrid!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You are a lying Whore! if I durst tell you so?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You Fellow! come hither.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Run, Gentil, run— Proffer him all I'm worth.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: (aside to Gentil) When we are gone; carry him to my Lodgings; I have told my Landlady the story, and she's provided for him.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: It shall be done— Is there no mercy?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ah, Lord, no mercy.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well! we'll be with you immediately— Come, Madam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Ay, ay, repent and pray, do 'Squire, do.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh Gentill! That ever I was born! That ever I was born!— What did he say to thee, Gentil?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: He wou'd have had me turned evidence against your Worship, and confess— But I'll be hang'd first?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I'd confess, if I thought 'twou'd do me any good?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What! Confess you murdered her!

sp.speaker: Cheat
sp.p: Ay, any thing! any thing! any thing— Oh Gentil! it must be this Witch— she has carried her away, and spilt the blood, that her Prophecy might come to pass?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Not unlikely,— Sir, Sir, I have thought of a thing.—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: What is't, dear Gentil?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Suppose you and I run away, before the Constable come, I know a Friend will conceal you, and then we may hope to make it up, or hear of her— I can't think she's murdered.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Nor I neither, except the Devil has don't? But let's away, good Gentil— methinks I hear this Magistrates paw,— this Constable just behind me, his voice hoarse with Watching, and swallowing Claret Bribes— Oh, Gentil! if I shou'd fall into his Gripe!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Therefore let's hasten to avoid it— Ah, Sir, this is no time for Jesting.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Too true, Gentil, but wit will o'reflow! I fear I shall quibble in my Prayers, and die with a Jest in my mouth— Come, come! Hang'd! O Lard, any of the Family of the Cheatalls hang'd! O Lard, and I the only branch on't? Oh, Gentil, 'tis unsupportable.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Away, away, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh that over I shou'd live to see my self hang'd.

div.stage: SCENE changes to a Chamber in the Temple. Enter Lywel in a Gown.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: So! I'm equipp'd: the young Lawyer snapp'd at the Guineas, and has furnish'd me throughout, nay, left his Boy to boot; Gad, I believe he'l be famous in his Generation, he encourages Mischief so readily. Pox!— wou'd they wou'd come— I'm weary of Cook upon Littleton.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, Sir,— a Gentleman and two Ladies are coming up.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: 'Tis they— you know your Cue.

div.stage: Enter Spendall, Lady Beauclair, and Mrs. Peggy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Young-man, is Councellor Smart within?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, he's dispatching some half a score Clients, but he'l do that with a wet Finger, and wait on you immediately.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A witty Whoreson; what, a wet Finger to lick up the Gold, ha!— Well, tell him I'm here.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Fine Chambers, Mother! and a sine place, I'll swear! 〈◊〉 Vather would ne'er let me walk here, zed, ' twan't sit for young Ladies.— I'll vaw, I like it waundily.

sp.speaker: La. Beau.
sp.p: Here were Councellors not unsit for you, but Husband was never free you should be seen.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Now I'm, by Promise, the happy man: my charming Dear, let me beg you'd entertain no other Thoughts.— Where's this Lawyer?— a Moments delay seems an Age.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Well, Daughter, feel how my Heart beats; I'm almost afraid to venture on him for thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Don't tell me of your Fears,— now you've put a Husband in my Head, I will be married, so I will.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Ah! send thee good Luck! I shall fall in a Fit, I believe, whilst thou art marrying.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I fear not marrying, not I.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p:
Well, Sir, I understand the business.— Your Father, considering your Extravagance, has done more than I thought sit to tell ye; but after
such a Proposal, you may hear it all— What! this is the pretty Creature, I suppose, you are about marrying.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Lord, Peggy, you're too forward! I wonder on ye now:— Sir, she is my Daughter, and she'll be worth Eight thousand pounds, and a better Penny; I would not have her cast away, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: To be thrown into a young Gentleman's Arms with a great Estate, will be a good Cast, I take it, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: If I were satisfied in that!

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: Look ye, Madam, I am a man of business, and many words are but supersluous.— Hum! hogh! D'ye see, here's the Settlement of his Father's Estate— Eight hundred pounds a Year, and some Thousands in Mony, a well-made Fellow into the bargain: Let me tell ye, Madam, such Offers don't stick o' hand now a-days; you may read the Writings if you please; if you dislike 'em— look ye, I have a Match in my Eye for the Gentleman beyond your Daughters; tho', I must own, this young Lady is much handsomer.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: (aside to her Mother) D'ye hear what he says now! you'll never leave your Impartinence, as Vather calls it,— Pray be quiet; I'm satisfied, so I am.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Will you read 'em, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: (reads) Noverint, &c.— Nay, Sir, I don't understand lay,— But you look like a good honest man, Sir, and I dare take your Word; I wish you had seen my Daughter sooner.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: (aside) Well said, Mother-in-law— that is to be in love with every new Face.— I must secure the young one, lest she's of the same mind.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: I'd willingly have him keep his Coach and six— I think the young Woman's Face will bear it— and their Estates, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: No doubt on't, Madam,— a handsom Wife, and a Coach and six, How it attracts all Eyes,— the Envy or the Wonder of the Park.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Well, you may do what you please, but the dear one and I are agreed.— we'l to Church without ye, if ye dispute it any longer.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay, and so we will, I vow and swear, Mr. Spendall.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: For shame, what d'ye talk on! why, 'tis past the Cannick hour.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Madam, all People of Quality marry at Night.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: That they may be sure to go to Bed, before they repent; a day's consideration might take off their Appetite.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Nay, if People of Quality do it, I'm for ye.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And so I am, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: First, Ladies, be pleas'd to visit my withdrawing Room, I have Sweet-meats and Trinkets there fit for the Fair sex, which secures me Female Visitants.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Agreed, we'l plunder him.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.l: Then we will seek to joyn this am'rous Pair,
And drown in Pleasure Thoughts of future Care.

sp.stage: Enter Flywife, pulling in Mrs. Flywife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Come, prithee Puggy, do.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: I'm not in humour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: What, don't you love none, Fubby?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: I hate Mankind, wou'd they were in one consuming blaze, tho'I were in the midst of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Hum, a consuming blaze; what's the matter now? this is some damn'd Intrigue has gone cross: I heard her bid Jenny come into this Room, and she'd be with her: That's a Quean, I dare swear, at the bottom; I'll creep behind the Hangings and hear their Discourse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: To be trick'd thus by a Boy, a Booby; sure this will humble the damn'd Opinion I have of my own Wit, and make me confess to my self, at least, I am a Fool.

sp.speaker: Jenn.
sp.p: Ay, your Ladiship was pleas'd to say, I might pass for his Nurse. Indeed I believe he has had as good Instructors, for I find he's old enough to be too cunning for his Benefactress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: What did he say when you parted?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Madam, I have told you several times; I no sooner shew'd him the House, but he leap'd back and seem'd surpriz'd; then recovering himself, he said, he would follow me in: I, according to your Directions, watch'd carefully, but no pretty Master came: Nothing vexes me so much, as that the little dissembling Sharper should get the Ring.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Pish, I don't value the Trifle three farthings; what's my doating Keeper good for, unless it be to give me more? But to lose the tempting Youth!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Pray add Sir Francis Wildlove's Loss to't:

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Peace, Fool; I'm thinking why the House should startle him; ha! is not here a sine Woman lodges, much retir'd, that seems of Quality?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; I never saw her but once, she's a perfect Charmer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: It must be so; this is some perdu Devil of hers, that durst not venture in, for fear his Constancy should be suspected: Pray watch who comes to her, dog 'em, do something for my ease.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Get me a Hackney-coach, I'll range the Town over, but I'll find Sir Francis Wildlove.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My Master will be mad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Then he may be sober agen, better he mad than I; if he be angry, 'tis but dissembling a little nauseous fondness, and all's well agen.

sp.speaker: Flyw.
sp.p: Is it so, thou worst Offspring of thy Grannam Eve? but I'll stifle my Rage, lest without further Proof she wheedles me into a Reconciliation, take another Coach and follow her, catch her amongst her Comrades, without the possibility of an Excuse, cut her Windpipe, and send her to Hell, without the possibility of a Reprieve: Damn her, damn her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The little hurry of my quick Remove has took up all my Thoughts, and I have not consider'd what I am about. See him no more, him whom I could not live a day, an hour, without! No more behold his Eye-balls, tremble with respectful passion!— Hear no more the soft falling Accents of his charming Tongue! view him dying at my feet no more!— O Virtue! take me to thee; chase from my strugling Soul all this fond tenderness: Secure me now, and I'm thy Votary for ever.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: Madam, neglecting even my Love, I come to wait on your Commands.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Such Thanks as an indiscreet and wretched Woman can return are yours: What said Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: He receiv'd the Message as Wretches that are afraid to dye, hear the condemning Voice, or as the Brave the loss of Victory, or the Ambitious that of Crowns: He begs, that he may haste to plead his Cause, and seems to live alone upon the Hopes his Love and Innocence may alter your Resolves.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O stop him, Sir, some moments longer, till I am just ready to be gone. He has a Friend too powerful within, and I must fly, or I shall never overcome.

sp.speaker: Beaum.
sp.p: I'll prevent his coming till you send. Your Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Honour and Love, oh the torture to think they are domestick foes, that must destroy the Heart that harbours 'em! Had my Glass but been my Idol, my Mind loose, unconstant, wavering, like my Sex, then I might have 'scap'd these pangs; Love, as passing Meteors, with several fires just warms their Breasts, and vanishes, leaving no killing Pain behind, 'tis only foolish: I have made a God of my Desire greater than ever the Poets feign'd: My Eyes receiv'd no Pleasure but what his sight gave me; no Musick charm'd my Ears, but his dear Voice: Wracks, Gibbets, and Dungeons, can they equal losing all my Soul admires? Why nam'd I them? Can there be greater Wracks
sp.l: Than what despairing parting Lovers find,
To part when both are true, both wou'd be kind?

div.trailer: The End of the fourth Act.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: HE comes, keep back, full Eyes, the springing Tears!— and thou poor trembling Heart! now be mann'd with all thy strongest stoutest Resolutions; there will be need.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Ah! whither shall I throw me? what shall I say?— Mariamne hangs like Iceicles upon my Tongue, but Bellinda flows: Oh Bellinda!— I charge thee by that dear Name, hear and pity me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: (coldly) What wou'd you say?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Why nothing; I do not know that Voice, it has stopp'd the rising words, and I must only answer with my sighs.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir Charles, we have both been punish'd with unwarrantable Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Punish'd! Have we been punish'd?— Now, by all my Woes to come, by all my Transports past, all thought of my Bellinda, there's not a Pang, a Groan, but brought: its pleasure with it: Oh! 'tis happier far to sigh for thee, than to have enjoy'd another.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You interrupt me when I just begin,— Grant it true,— we might have liv'd till weary grown of one another, till you, perhaps, might coldly say, I had a Mistress.— Now to part, when at the mention of each other's Name our Hearts will rise, our Eyes run o'er, 'tis better much than living to indifferency, which Time and Age would certainly have brought.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Oh, never, never; tho' the Bauble gaudy Beauty die, yet Sence and Humour still remain— on that I should have doated.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You cannot guess your future by your present Thoughts; or, if you cou'd, I am not to be mov'd forsaking thee; and when I have said that, I need not add all Pleasures,— in remote and unfrequented shades I'll pass my solitary hours, and like a Recluse, waste the remalnder of my wretched days.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: And am I the Cause of this melancholy penance? Must my unhappy Love rob the World of its fairest Ornament? No, Madam, stay and injoyn me what you please; condemn my Tongue to everlasting silence; let me now and then but gaze, and tell you with my Eyes what's acting in my Heart; or— if you will retire, permit me to follow, under the pretence of hunting; the Air, a thousand things I can invent, create new Friendship, caress the whole Country o'er, to have an opportunity of seeing you, though at a hateful distance, and surrounded by severost Friends.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! is this the awful Love, I thought possess'd ye? How fatally I was mistaken! What! pursue me to my Father's House! fix on my Name a lasting Blot, a Deathless Infamy, pollute my Native Air with unhallow'd Love, where all my Ancestors have, for Ages, flourish'd, and left an honest Fragrancy behind! Mark me, Sir, you know I do not use to break my word.— If by Letters, Messages, or the least appearance (tho' cautiously, as Treasons plotted against the State) you approach me, I'll fly the Kingdom, or, if that's too little, the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: No, 'tis I have been mistaken.— Now, by all the Wracks I feel, not worth a Sigh, a parting drop; no Regard of Tenderness, no Beam of Pity, from those dear Eyes, nor sidelong Glance to view my sad Distraction! Methinks you have already left me, and I am got amongst my Fellow Madmen, tearing my Hair, chain'd to the Ground, foaming, and digging up the Earth, yet in every smallest Interval of Sence calling on Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A noble Birth, a censorious World, a mourning Father, all plead against thee. Oh, talk no more, lest you force my Hand to some desperate Act; and yet your Words pierce my Bosom with greater pain than pointed Steel.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I see you are resolv'd on my Undoing, fix'd like my relentless Fate; therefore I'll not urge another syllable, but quietly, as dying Men when Hope's all past, quit Life and their dearest Friends, for ever, ever leave thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That sad silent Look discovers such inward Worlds of Woe, it strikes me through, staggers my best Resolves, removes the Props I have been raising for my sinking Fame, and, blind with passion, I could reel into thy Arms.— Tell me, on what are thy Thoughts employ'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: On the Curse of Life, impos'd on us without our Choice, and almost always attended with tormenting Plagues.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yet we may meet again, in Peace and Joy, when this Gigantick Honour appears no Bugbear, and our Desires lawfully be crown'd.— It is a guilty Thought; nor shall I ever dare to form it to a Wish.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: But dost thou think we may? [embracing her.]
What! uncontroul'd clasp thee thus! Oh, Extasie! with wild Fury run o'er each trembling beauteous Limb, and grasp thee as drowning Men the dear Bark from whence they were thrown.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Away, away! What are we doing? Divide him, Heaven, from my fond guilty Eyes; set Seas, and Earth, and Worlds of Fire between us, for Virtue, Fate, and Honour, with an united Cry, have doom'd, that we must meet no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: To raging Seas, Sieges, and Fields of Battle will I fly, Pleasures and Pastimes to the Woes I feel. Oh, Bellinda!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I cou'd laugh my Heart sore, to see what a condition the Fool my Master's in; every knocking at the Door is as good as a Dose of Rubarb, and every Noise makes him leap like a Vaulter. Ha! he's coming, the poor Baby dares not be alone.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Gentil! Is the Coast clear?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh Gentil!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What's the matter? You look worse frighted than you were.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay, and well I may; you leave me alone, and I shall grow distracted: I have I have seen a Ghost.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: A Ghost! what, Mrs. Arabella's Ghost?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Nay, I did not stay to examin that; for, as soon as ever I perceiv'd the Glympse on't, I shut up my Eyes, and felt my way out of the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Where was this Ghost, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh! behind the Bed, behind the Bed, Gentil.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, 'twas nothing but the Cloak; I hung it there.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Was it not? O' my Conscience, I thought it had been a Giant of a Ghost.— Hark, hark! what's that?
sp.stage: (A Cry without, seeming at a distance.

sp.speaker: Boy without.
sp.p: A full and true Relation of a horrid and bloody Murther, committed on the Body of Mrs. Arabella Venturewell, a young Lady, by one 'Squire Barnaby Cheatall and his Man Gentil; shewing how they lock'd her up in the dark, then cut her to pieces, and carried the pieces away under their Cloaks, and threw 'em into Chelsey-Reach, where, at low Water, they were f●…d.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: O Lard! O Lard! the pieces found, Gentil!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: So it seems, Sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: (seeming farther off) A full and true Relation of a, &c.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Nay, now we shall be hang'd for certain; not the least Hopes: Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Come, Sir, have a little Courage.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: To confess the truth to thee, I never had any Courage in my Life; and this would make the stoutest man tremble: Oh!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I am thinking, Sir,— why— we was not at Chelsey-Reach that day.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: No, no; but, may be, they'l swear we was.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: My Lady and Miss hated her,— sure they han't been so barbarous.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Like enough,— pin-up Petticoats are as convenient as Cloaks,— besides, my Sister is a Fury; I've heard her threaten pulling Folks a pieces a hundred times, and now she has don't.— We'l e'en peach.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What, your own Sister!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay, my own Mother, to save my self:— I say, we'l peach.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: That's not so good, for if they prove themselves innocent, 'twill fall upon us agen.— Heark ye, Sir, there's only Eugenia can witness against us,— suppose we try'd to stifle her Evidence with a swindging Bribe; I never knew a Chambermaid refuse greasing in the Fist upon any Account.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: My dear Gentil,— if she inclines, my Offers shall be so large, that for the rest of her Life she shall have nothing to do, but study to make her Hands white, that she may burn all her Frippery, and be able to spark it with Quality.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Sir, I ll send her Propositions.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: (half draws his Sword) Do, but if the stubborn Jade won't comply, appoint a private meeting, and stop her Mouth with this— 〈◊〉 you understand me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.
I find his Conscience would swallow a real Murder.— Sir, if you please, we'll go in and write what you design to offer her.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Let us. If you meet her, Gentil, and she's surly,— Remember,— ugh,— ugh.

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Wildlove, and to him Searchwell.

sp.speaker: Searchw.
sp.p: Sir Charles sends you word, he is ba●…e ordering his Affairs, designing with all speed to travel, and says, he shall never see you more, only to take his leave.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Hey day! O' my Conscience, this charming little Beauclair has me under a Spell, and I shall meet with nothing but Disappointments till I submit to her.

sp.speaker: Searchw.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, you wou'd soon find the true Pleasures of virtuous Love, and a satisfaction in denying your Appetite.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Preaching Fool, hold you your Peace.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, a Gentlewoman below desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Searchw.
sp.p: (aside) So, there's no great danger my Master shou'd Reform, when the Devil is alwaies at hand with a Temptation in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Searchwell, wait on the Lady up.

sp.speaker: Searchw.
sp.p: Ah Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Sirrah, I shall break your Head, if you don't leave this canting trade.

sp.speaker: Searchw.
sp.p: I am gone, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dressw.
sp.p: (aside) This is a mad Message my Lady has sent me with to her Lover; I'm afraid he'l kick me for my News; hang't, he's a Gentleman, and I'll venture.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Ha! pretty Mrs. Dreswell, this is a favour I never receiv'd from you before; Must I own the Blessing only to your Good-will, or is my Happiness greater? Did your Lady send?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dressw.
sp.p: I came from my Lady, Sir, but what Happiness you'l find I know not; methinks she has done a strange mad thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dressw.
sp.p: She's married, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra.
sp.p: The Devil she is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dressw.
sp.p: Even so: she said, those that she fancied car'd not for her, therefore she resolv'd to bestow her self and Fortunes on a secret Lover, whom indeed her Ladiship owns she never valued, a Gentleman you know, sir, the worthy Mr. Spendall.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: (walks about enrag'd) Damnation! that Rake, Bully, Sharper! damn it, damn it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dressw.
sp.p: Here's a Note where they are; she desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Tell her I esteem her so much, I'll cut the Rascal's Throat she has thought sit to call Husband; I'll do it, Madam, tho' I'm hang'd at the Door; 'tis the only way I can express my Love to her now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dressw.
sp.p: Wou'd I were well gone; I'll tell her, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Married! and to Spendall! Oh, that I cou'd despise her: Ha! I find 'tis worse with me than I thought, what makes this gnaw my Heart so else? My fellow-Libertines will laugh to see me play the fool and kill my self: Oh, I cou'd tear in piecemeal the Villain that betray'd her to endless Ruin.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, there's another Lady, out of a Coach, coming up stairs.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Blockhead, tell her I desire she would break her Neck down agen, and oblige me in riding post to the Devil. My Coach there?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: O my Nose, my Nose; why what's the matter now? I thought I should have had a Reward for my News; and so I have, I think. O, my Nose.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: Where's Sir Francis? Did you tell him I was coming up?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, and he says, you may go to the Devil, he has spoil'd the Ornament of my face, and flung into his Coach stark mad.

sp.speaker: Mrs Fly.
sp.p: Much of Passion shows much of Love, my Coach shall follow his, I'll not leave him so.

div.stage: SCENE changes. Enter Mrs. Beauclair, Dresswell and a Woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p:
I must confess I am Fool enough to be pleas'd with Sir Francis's concern? But, Oh, my Uncle's troubles draws a vail upon my rising Joys, and damps all Mirth: Poor Bellinda! she sent a Note to tell me her Disorder was
such, she cou'd not see me; with much ado I have perswaded Sir Charles to come hither, for half an hour, and look into this unlucky piece of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Madam, they are coming.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: In, in, then?

div.stage: Enter Lady Beauclair, Spendall, Miss Peggy, Lywell.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: Here give me a Glass of Wine, Mrs. Bride's long life, and lasting happiness.

sp.speaker: M. Peg.
sp.p: Thank ye, Sir, give me a Glass, you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: To me, my Love?

sp.speaker: M. Peg.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yours, for ever.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Lard, Child, you'll drink too much Wine.

sp.speaker: M. Peg.
sp.p: Pray be quiet, I'll drink what I please; I am Married now, why sure, I'll ha' none of your Tutoring, I Cod, I'll long for every thing I see, shan't I, you?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I, and have it too, my dear.

sp.speaker: M. Peg.
sp.p: I Cod, I'll long for Green Pease at Christmas, so I will.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: My heart akes, this great concern has made me sick, give me a Glass.

sp.speaker: M. Peg.
sp.p: I am Mothers own Daughter, feth I dare confess it now, I always us'd to be sick for a Glass of Wine, ho, ho?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Sure the Wench is mad

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Ha, dear Ladies go in, 'tis some body from Sir Charles, I believe, I wou'd willingly speak with 'em first.

sp.speaker: M. Peg.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let's go in, there's more Wine within.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Be sure you make your Estate out plain.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, yes, heark ye, Lywell, carry 'em out of Ear-shot, lest it shou'd prove a Dunner.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: I warrant; Come Ladies, we'll in, and take a Bumper.

sp.speaker: M. Peg.
sp.p: O la, you make me so blush—

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Boy, open the door?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What, grown so great already, that I must wait half an hour for admittance.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: (aside.) He is come from Sir Charles, I ll speak him fair: Sir Francis Wildlove, your very humble servant, I beg ten thousand Pardons.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Keep your fawning, and bestow it on Fools; 'tis lost on me, and will be grosly answer'd. I tell ye, you are a Rascal.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Poverty makes many a man so, Sir

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: A presuming Rascall do I not know thee for the dreg of humane kind, and shall thy detested Arms receive her Virgin Beauties; life of goodness, Soul of Honour, Wit, and Sweetness, the only Woman upon Earth I cou'd have lov'd?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Sure you design to banter me: Soul of Wit, and Sweetness; the Devil might had her Sweetness for me. 'Twas her Mony I married; faith, Sir Francis, I always took her for a Fool?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Prophaner! this last action only calls her Judgment in question, thy Death is Justice, first to deceive, and then abuse her, draw.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I will draw, tho', Gad, I wou'd have sworn, never to have fought on this occasion.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Beauclair and Dresswell laughing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, I'll not disturb your mirth, but be so calm to wish it may continue.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this? how came Mrs. Beauclair here?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Are you not married to this Lady?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No such Honour was ever designed for me: Lard, Sir, I am married to Miss Peggy, Lady Beauclair's Daughter, my Fool's within, now I hope I may call her

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: I 〈◊〉, Sir Francis, you Counterplotted me, knew the truth, and only acted this concern.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: No, by Heaven, nor perfectly my own heart, till this severe Trial search'd it; did I dissemble, Madam, your sense wou'd soon discover it, but by my Soul, I love you truly, and if you dare venture on me, my future life shall shew how much I honour you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Can you then leave all the pretty City Wives, which a Man of your Parts and 〈◊〉, in a quarter of an hours seige, could overcome? In fine, all the charming variety of what was pretty, or agreeable in the whole Sex, and he confin'd? Oh, that's a hard word to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: With more delight than those surfc●…ing Joys (that always left a sting behind 'em) afforded.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if you can give me your heart, I can allow you great Liberties: but when we have play'd the Fool and married, don't you when you have been pleased abroad, come heare surly: let your looks be kind, your Conversation easie, and tho I shoud know you have been with a Mistress, I'd meet you with a smile.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: When I forsake such Charms, for senseless mercenary Creatures, you shall correct me with the greatest punishment upon Earth, a frown.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: You'll fall into the Romantick stile, Sir Francis: Mr. Spendall, shan't we see your Bride?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and I hope your Ladyship will prove my Friend to Sir Charles.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we'll all speak for ye; had she mist ye, there was no great likelihood, as the case was, she wou'd have done better.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Where is the pretty Miss? pray conduct us to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Sir Charles will be here presently, I long to hear my Aunt set out the greatness of the match.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: This way, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Beaumont, Arabella and Engenia.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Is this the House, Enge●…ia?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well, thou art a lucky Girl, to recover my Writings with such speed.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Madam, the 'Squire wou'd have parted with a limb, if I had requir'd it.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Madam, it was your promise, whenever you possest your Fortune, (tho' I'm sure I never insisted on't) you wou'd be mine.

sp.speaker: Arab
sp.p: I have no occasion to break my word, Mr. Beaumont.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Then I am happy.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Mrs. Eugenia, will you enquire where these Bride-folks are?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: See, Madam, they are coming.

div.stage: Enter Lady Beauclair, Mrs. Beauclair, Miss Peggy, Sir Francis Wildlove, Spendall, Lywell.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Will the 'Squire be here?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I told him of his Cousin's Marriage, and he seems pleased his Sister has been trick'd.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Lard, you, what d'ye bring one to these folks, they'll do nothing but jeer us?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Oh, my dear, carry your self civily, and every body will love ye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Sir Charles will be here presently to wish you Joy, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: So, then we shall have noise enough, but I'll be as loud as he, I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: And louder too, or I'm mistaken.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Neice, why have you dragg'd me to this unwilling Pennance, if the Girl is ruin'd what is't to me? my thoughts are full of something else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: My Uncle, my Father, and my Friend, yet these names do not express half my tenderness: The best of Guardians and of Men: pray change your thoughts of Travel, I'll study ten thousand things for your Diversion.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Not Angels Eloquence shou'd alter me; I'll act the uneasie part no longer, that Woman, the bar to all my Happiness, by Heaven, she's not my Wife: 'tis true, the Ceremony of the Church has pass'd between us, but she knows I went no further.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Stay then, and live asunder.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No; so, Madam, you've married your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Yes, what then? he has a good Estate, when his Father dies, beside the present settlement, and ready Mony.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Poor deluded Women! he has no Estate, nor Relation worth owning, Mr. Spendall, generous Charity induced me to relieve your wants, you have betray'd this young woman, but use her well— I have not much to say— I suppose they were both so willing, a very little pains effected the matter.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: How, Rascal! Devil! have ye married my Daughter— and have ye nothing, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Ask Mrs. Peggy that.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You make one laugh, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Beast! I don't mean so— But have ye no Estate, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, faith, Madam, not I; my Wife has enough for us both, and what's matter.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Oh, Dog! Come away, Peggy, we'll go to Doctors Commons, and thou shalt be Divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I won't be Divorc'd, I've got a Husband, and I don't care, I'll stay with him.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: That's kindly said, and I engage you shan't repent it.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why Counsellor Smart, why Counsellor Smart, did not ye tell me—

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Hey day, Counsellor Smart! why this is a Fellow many degrees worse than your new Son in-Law. Hearkye Friend, leave this Counterfeiting Trade— or you'll lose your Ears; Reform, as your Friend has done, and Marry.

sp.speaker: Lyw.
sp.p: Hang him, Rogue: He's a Smock-fac'd Fellow, and Handsom: I shall do no good with the Women.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: (aside) Go, be gone, Devil, don't disgrace me, I'll meet you at the old place.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Look what a puff the old Lady's in— Aunt, you always said you'd match your Daughter your self, you did not desire a cunninger head than your own.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well, Mrs. Flippant! I hope your mad tricks will bring you a Bastard home at last, and that will be worse.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, spare my Neice: she ever was most repectful to you, till you abus'd her beyond all bearing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Mind not a mad Woman.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Your Servant Gentiles!— O La! Sister, I hear strange news, Cousin Peggy's married to a Sharper, a Rake, a Bully, they say! I told you so, I told you so! Gadzooks! you wou'd not be warn'd.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well, Booby! what's that to you, underhead.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Pox take your nasty Fist! you love sighting plaguily.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well, 'twas passion, you may excuse it, when you consider my afflictions— To make ye amends, I'll come live with you, and take care of your Estaté, and Mrs. Arabella's.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: No, no, don't mistake your self, I'll be a stingy Cur no longer, but drink my Bottle freely, nor sneak out o' the Company without paying my Club, for fear of having my Pocket examined by you.
O Lard! the Ghost! the Ghost.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What, is the man mad?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: You don't understand the whim.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Come gi' me thy hand, old Boy, we'll be Friends; I am no Ghost, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: And— is not that the Hectoring Spark your Brother, with his monsterous whiskers par'd?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Not her Brother, Sir, but one who hopes to pretend to the Lady, by another Title.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh! I find how matters ha'been carried— Much good may d'ye with her— Gadzooks, she wa'n't sit for me,— I'm a Fool, you know, Sister.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You must grant me one Request.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: To forgive Gentil; he's going to be married to Eugenia, but shall have no Joys without your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I forgive him, and leave his Wife to punish him; she has a Fruitful Invention, let him take care it does not one day fall upon his own head— Gentil! I am Friends; and will give thee something towards House-keeping.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I'm sure, it went to my very heart to fright your Worship so.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You are a wheedling Baggage; but 'tis all well, I'm contented.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Flywife, in a fright.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: O save me! save me! I'm pursued by a bloody-minded Monster.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What's the matter? is it your Husband, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: 'Tis my Tyrant, the Devil 'tis.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Nay, hold ye, Mistress, don't ye run behind me; udsbores, so I may have the sword in my Guts by mistake.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: We'll all protect the Lady.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Protect! damnation; do but hear how vile a thing it is.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Hear! what do I hear, and see! why, sure this is our Brother Allen, my Sister's first Husband, we thought dead in the Indies.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: What's that? speak agen, but speak a loud, lest I shou'd only catch the sound of Happiness, and be deceived.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Has my damn'd Jilt brought me to a greater plague, my Wife? but I'll own it to punish her, tho' I suffer an abominable torment till next fair wind, the Sea's my Element; once there, I'm free. Well, I confess I have found a Wife here. Why stare you so? I am not the first has thought the sight unpleasing.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No, no, talk on; all are hush'd, as if a midnight silence reigned.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Who's this? Are you my first Husband Allen? And did you pretend you was dead, rather than come home to me, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Here's a sine greeting.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: How! your Husband! he's mine before Heaven: Mr. Flywise, won't vou own me. Fubby?

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: In troth, I think there's scarce a Pin to chuse; but you have disoblig'd me last, therefore avant, Strumpet, come hither, thou natural noisie Spouse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: That Shape and Face prefer'd to me?

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: I'll be reveng'd of her, I'm resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: I'm all Amazement, Sir Francis; save the Lady, because she was my Friend; return her Ring, that may help console her.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: (parting 'em) Hold, Ladies, Ladies: March off, here's the bountiful Present; come, come, I doubt not but you've a private Pocket.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Flyw.
sp.p: The Devil take you all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beaum.
sp.p: What Miracle is this? Madam, leave your passion, and explain it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Peg.
sp.p: Is my own Vather come agen? O La.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Your own Vather come agen! O La! Then, I fear, your Portion is not at your own dispose, Miss.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Peg.
sp.p: Good Lord! does that disturb ye?

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: Gentlemen, now your Wonder is a little over, pray let me ask why all this Company, and why that Gentleman, whom I know not, appears transported.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Sir; 'twas my hard Fate to marry your Lady, before your death was well confirm'd, that kept it some time private, when, before we came together, a Quarrel, from her uneasie Temper, arose, and I swore never to bed her; yet, for our Friends and Conveniency's sake, we seem'd to live like Man and Wife. Speak; Madam, is not this true?

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis true, the more shame for ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Here, Sir, receive her, and with her a new Date of Happiness.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: I guess my future Happiness by the past; but since it must be so—

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Dear Neice, go to my House, and deliver up whatever is that Lady's.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: You'l send to Bellinda?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.l: My self, my self shall be the Messenger;
In my eager Mind I'm already there:
Methinks the Earth's enchanted, and I tread on Air.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: So, there's one pleas'd, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Well, Brother, you're welcome home, as I may say: Why, here's Cousin Peggy grown up and married since you went.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.p: What! Is that Bud come to the Blossom of Matrimony? all by the Mother's Contrivance; a wise business, I Believe. Sir, I shall make bold to examin into your Estate before I give my Daughter any.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Say ye so? and if you give your Daughter none, I shall prove a second Mr. Flywife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Peg.
sp.p: What's that, Bold-face?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Nothing, Child.

sp.speaker: La. Beauc.
sp.p: Ay, that's a hopeful Match; I could find in my Heart to lock my self up, and never see your ugly Faces agen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beaum.
sp.p: Let's follow, and appease her.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And as we go, you shall tell me what makes Sir Charles thus overjoy'd:

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beaum.
sp.p: I will; and when we have done what he desir'd, we'll go all to Bellinda's, there we shall find my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Come, Beaumont, let's see the end of this surprizing Accident.

sp.speaker: Mr. Flyw.
sp.l: How like a Dog a Man looks once escap'd!
Forc'd back into the Matrimonial Noose;
'Tis a damn'd Joy to find the Wife I'd loose.
sp.stage: SCENE, Bellinda's Apartment. On a Table lies her Hood and Scarf.
sp.p: Sure some unseen Power holds me a moment longer; ah! 'tis no Power, but foolish Love, that shows the paths which carries me from Beauclair, leading to Death, or, what's worse, Despair.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Madam, the Coach is ready.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm coming, be sure you let none have admittance.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I will not, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! my Lady charg'd you should not enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Away, you Trifler; where's my Bellinda?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is unmanly; not conquer your Desires, nor obey my positive Commands!

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Oh, stay and hear me; let me hang upon your Knees, for I am out of breath, clasp and prattle o'er thee, like a glad Mother when she hugs her first-born Blessing after the pangs of Death; mine, like hers, is Folly all, but full of Fondness.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh:

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Sigh not, my Fair; by Heaven I am free from any Chains but thine, free as thy own clear Soul's from Vice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How! what mean ye? oh, rise, and stop my growing Fears, Where's your Wife? is she well?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Think not so basely of me, she's well, and in her Husband's Arms, oh, my Bellinda! in her Husband's Arms; her first and only Husband, Allen, is return'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Forgetting all colder nicer forms, in thy faithful Bosom let me receive such News.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: My Life.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Soul. (embracing.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Ha! the transporting Joy has caught her Rosie Breath, and those bright Eyes are in their snowy Lids retir'd: Oh, this is more, much more than ten thousand words cou'd have express'd. ' Wake, my Bellinda, 'tis thy Beauclair calls.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do not view my blushing Face, I fear I have offended that Virgin Modesty by me still practis'd and ador'd; now we must stand on forms, till time and decency shall crown our Wishes.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: My Goddess, Conqueress, by thee for ever I am directed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I know thy honest Heart so well, I do not scruple the truth of what you have said.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: You need not, Dearest; see, all our Friends come to confirm it.

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Wildlove, Beaumont, Cheatall, Mrs. Beauclair and Arabella.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beauc.
sp.p: Joy to my dear Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Permit a stranger to rejoyce at the Reward of Virtue and constant Love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pardon my Answers, Ladies, when I confess I scarce know where I am.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Now I can mind the Affairs of my Friend; Sir Francis, I observe you very assiduous to my Neice, has she receiv'd you for her servant? and are you resolv'd on the truest Happiness, Constancy?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Yes faith, Sir Charles, I am the Lady's Dog in a string, and have violent pantings towards the delicious Charmer; I hope she won't long deferr my Desires: But let that black Gentleman I've so long dreaded do his worst, he shan't spoil my stomach.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beauc.
sp.p: Ah! those pantings, Sir Francis, I doubt they have mov'd your stomach so often, till they've quite took it away.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: A little forbearance, and such a tempting meal—

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: [to Mr. Beaumont] You, Sir, too are blest; I read it in your Eyes, and see the Lady with ye.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beaum.
sp.p: I fear no danger now, but dying of that pleasing Feaver call'd Rapture.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: To any man's thinking, these now are going to Heaven ding dong: but hear me, Ladies; 'faith, all young handsom fellows talk just so before Matrimony: seven Years hence let me bear of Pantings, Heavings, and Raptures; no, Gadzooks, scarce Risings then: I shall live a jolly Batchelor, and laugh at your Indifference, Gadzooks, I shall—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Beau.
sp.p: Well said 'Squire; we wou'd bring him along, Sir Charles, I think him very good-humour'd to this Lady, and believe his Sister only made him otherwise.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I read in every Face a pleasing Joy, but you must give me leave to think that mine exceeds, rais'd to unexpected Worlds of Bliss, when sunk in Sorrows and Despair.
sp.l: Kind Fate, beyond my Hopes, the Weight remov'd,
And gave me all, in giving her I lov'd.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: BY a mistake in the Copy, which was false Folio'd, the Scene in Sir Charles Beauclair's House, Pag. 32, should have came in, in the latter part of the third Act, which ends with,
Cheat. Oh, that ever I should live to see my self hang'd.
